וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: בְּאַחֵיכֶם — מִסֵּיפָא דִּקְרָא נָפְקָא: ״וּבְאַחֵיכֶם בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל אִישׁ בְּאָחִיו לֹא תִרְדֶּה בוֹ בְּפָרֶךְ״.

וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתִיב ״וּבְאַחֵיכֶם״, כְּתִיב נָמֵי ״בָּהֶם״. לְכִדְתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: כָּל פָּרָשָׁה שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרָה וְנִישְׁנֵית, לֹא נִישְׁנֵית אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל דָּבָר שֶׁנִּתְחַדֵּשׁ בָּהּ.

אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: זְנוּתָא בְּבֵיתָא כִּי קַרְיָא לְשׁוּמְשְׁמָא. וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: תּוּקְפָּא בְּבֵיתָא כִּי קַרְיָא לְשׁוּמְשְׁמָא. אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי בְּאִיתְּתָא, אֲבָל בְּגַבְרָא לֵית לַן בַּהּ.

וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: בַּתְּחִילָּה, קוֹדֶם שֶׁחָטְאוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל, הָיְתָה שְׁכִינָה שׁוֹרָה עִם כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ מִתְהַלֵּךְ בְּקֶרֶב מַחֲנֶךָ״. כֵּיוָן שֶׁחָטְאוּ נִסְתַּלְּקָה שְׁכִינָה מֵהֶם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא יִרְאֶה בְךָ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר וְשָׁב מֵאַחֲרֶיךָ״.

אָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: כׇּל הָעוֹשֶׂה מִצְוָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — מְקַדַּמְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָלַךְ לְפָנֶיךָ צִדְקֶךָ״. וְכׇל הָעוֹבֵר עֲבֵירָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — מְלַפַּפְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לְיוֹם הַדִּין, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״יִלָּפְתוּ אׇרְחוֹת דַּרְכָּם יַעֲלוּ בַתֹּהוּ וְיֹאבֵדוּ״.

רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: קְשׁוּרָה בּוֹ כְּכֶלֶב, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא שָׁמַע אֵלֶיהָ לִשְׁכַּב אֶצְלָהּ לִהְיוֹת עִמָּהּ״. ״לִשְׁכַּב אֶצְלָהּ״ — בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה, ״לִהְיוֹת עִמָּהּ״ — לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא.
תְּנַן הָתָם, שֶׁהָיָה בַּדִּין:

וּמָה עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינָהּ מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם, עֵדוּת הָאַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא תִּתְקַיֵּים בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם?
תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְעֵד אֵין בָּהּ״, כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהּ.

וְקַל וָחוֹמֶר לְעֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה מֵעַתָּה: וּמָה עֵדוּת הָאַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּעֵד אֶחָד, עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁתִּתְקַיֵּים בְּעֵד אֶחָד?

תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״, וּלְהַלָּן הוּא אוֹמֵר ״עַל פִּי שְׁנֵי עֵדִים אוֹ עַל פִּי שְׁלֹשָׁה עֵדִים יָקוּם דָּבָר״. מָה ״דָּבָר״ הָאָמוּר לְהַלָּן — עַל פִּי שְׁנַיִם עֵדִים, אַף כָּאן — עַל פִּי שְׁנַיִם.
הַאי מִ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״ נָפְקָא? מִ״בָּהּ״ נָפְקָא: בָּהּ — וְלֹא בְּקִינּוּי, בָּהּ — וְלֹא בִּסְתִירָה מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
הָכִי נָמֵי קָאָמַר: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״בָּהּ״: בָּהּ — וְלֹא בְּקִינּוּי, בָּהּ — וְלֹא בִּסְתִירָה.

וְטוּמְאָה בְּעָלְמָא בְּלֹא קִינּוּי וּבְלֹא סְתִירָה, דְּלָא מְהֵימַן עֵד אֶחָד, מְנָלַן? נֶאֱמַר כָּאן: ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן: ״עַל פִּי שְׁנֵי עֵדִים אוֹ עַל פִּי שְׁלֹשָׁה עֵדִים יָקוּם דָּבָר״. מָה ״דָּבָר״ הָאָמוּר לְהַלָּן — עֵדִים שְׁנַיִם, אַף כָּאן — עֵדִים שְׁנַיִם.
תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵי זוֹ הִיא עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה — זוֹ עֵדוּת סְתִירָה, עֵדוּת אַחֲרוֹנָה — זוֹ עֵדוּת טוּמְאָה.
llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva - If so, it should have been written "to her" and should have been silenced, "he shall be unclean" - why do I need it? Learn from it.

Rabbi Yishmael, through the fact that it is written "lah," wrote "yittama." As it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael. For it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: Any portion that was stated and repeated, was repeated only because of a matter that was newly introduced in it.
"Forever in them you shall serve" - permission, the words of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: obligation.

What is the reason for Rabbi Yishmael's opinion? - Because it is written, "You shall not let any soul remain alive," it was also necessary for it to be written, "You shall surely destroy them." This is to include even one of all the nations that came upon the Canaanite woman and fathered a son from her, that you are permitted to acquire him.

It was taught in a Baraita: From where do we derive that one of the nations that came upon the Canaanite and fathered a son from her, that you are permitted to acquire him as a slave? The verse teaches: "And also from the children of the residents who dwell among you, from them you may acquire."

One might have thought that even a Canaanite who came from one of the nations and fathered a son from her, that you are permitted to acquire him as a slave, the verse teaches: "Those that are born in your land," from those born in your land, and not from the strangers in your land.
Rabbi Akiva said: "From them they established." It emerged, "Forever in them you shall serve." Why do I need it? - For an obligation.
Rabbi Yishmael: "bahem" - and not in your brothers.
Rabbi Akiva: "Among your brothers" - derived from the end of the verse: "But among your brothers, the children of Israel, a man shall not rule over his brother with severity."

Rabbi Yishmael: Through what is written "and in your brothers," it is also written "in them." Based on the teaching of the school of Rabbi Yishmael. For it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: Every portion that was said and repeated, it was repeated only because of a matter that was newly introduced in it.

Rav Ḥisda said: Immorality in the home is like calling for the demon. And Rav Ḥisda said: A palm tree in the home is like calling for the demon. Both of them are harmful, but with a man, we have no concern about it.

And Rav Hisda said: Initially, before the Israelites sinned, the Divine Presence dwelled among each and every one of them, as it is stated: "For the Lord your God walks in the midst of your camp." Once they sinned, the Divine Presence departed from them, as it is stated: "And He will not see any indecency among you and turn away from you."

Said Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said Rabbi Yonatan: Anyone who performs one mitzvah in this world - it precedes him and goes before him to the World to Come, as it is stated: "And your righteousness will go before you." And anyone who commits one transgression in this world - it surrounds him and goes before him on the day of judgment, as it is stated: "Their ways will be tangled in darkness, and they will be lost."
Rabbi Elazar says: tied to him like a dog, as it is stated: "And he did not listen to her to lie with her, to be with her." "to lie with her" - in this world, "to be with her" - in the world to come.
We learned there, that he was in judgment:

The Talmudic text translates as follows: "And what is the testimony of the first witness, that you do not prohibit it with a permanent prohibition - it is not upheld with less than two witnesses. The testimony of the last witness, that you do prohibit it with a permanent prohibition - is it not a law that is not upheld with less than two witnesses?"
The Talmud teaches: "And there is no witness in her," anything that has in it.

And light and heavy for the testimony of the first from now: And what is the testimony of the latter, that you prohibit it with a perpetual prohibition — it is upheld by one witness, the testimony of the first, that you do not prohibit it with a perpetual prohibition — is it not a law that can be upheld by one witness?

The Talmud teaches: "For he found in her the nakedness of a matter," and elsewhere it says, "By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established." What is the "matter" mentioned there? By the mouth of two witnesses. So too here - by the mouth of two witnesses.
This is the case of "if he found in her a matter of nakedness" derived? "In her" derived: in her - and not in betrothal, in her - and not in concealment is required!
So did Nami say: The Talmud teaches "in it": in it - and not in a euphemism, in it - and not in a concealment.

Talmudic text: And impurity in general without designation and without contradiction, for not believed one witness, from where? It is stated here: "For he found in her the nakedness of a thing," and it is stated there: "By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established." What is the "matter" mentioned there - two witnesses, so too here - two witnesses.
The Rabbis taught: What is the first testimony? — This is contradictory testimony. What is the last testimony? — This is testimony of impurity.

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: ״בָּהֶם״ — וְלֹא בְּאַחֵיכֶם.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Yishmael “of them,” but not of your brethren,
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael: "bahem" - and not in your brothers.

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: בְּאַחֵיכֶם — מִסֵּיפָא דִּקְרָא נָפְקָא: ״וּבְאַחֵיכֶם בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל אִישׁ בְּאָחִיו לֹא תִרְדֶּה בוֹ בְּפָרֶךְ״.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Akiva your brethren is derived from the latter of the verse, “But over your brethren the children of Israel you shall not rule, one over another, with rigor”
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva: "Among your brothers" - derived from the end of the verse: "But among your brothers, the children of Israel, a man shall not rule over his brother with severity."

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתִיב ״וּבְאַחֵיכֶם״, כְּתִיב נָמֵי ״בָּהֶם״. לְכִדְתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: כָּל פָּרָשָׁה שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרָה וְנִישְׁנֵית, לֹא נִישְׁנֵית אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל דָּבָר שֶׁנִּתְחַדֵּשׁ בָּהּ.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Yishmael since it is written: “But over your brethren,” it also writes “of them,” because of that was taught by the school of Rabbi Yishmael. As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Every passage that was stated and repeated, was repeated only for the novel element introduced therein.
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael: Through what is written "and in your brothers," it is also written "in them." Based on the teaching of the school of Rabbi Yishmael. For it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: Every portion that was said and repeated, it was repeated only because of a matter that was newly introduced in it.

sentences.text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: זְנוּתָא בְּבֵיתָא כִּי קַרְיָא לְשׁוּמְשְׁמָא. וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: תּוּקְפָּא בְּבֵיתָא כִּי קַרְיָא לְשׁוּמְשְׁמָא. אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי בְּאִיתְּתָא, אֲבָל בְּגַבְרָא לֵית לַן בַּהּ.
sentences.human_translation: Rav Ḥisda says: Licentious in a home like a worm [ karya ] to sesame [ shumeshema ]. And Rav Ḥisda says: Anger in a home like a worm to sesame. this and that, with regard to the woman but with regard to the man, we do not have with regard to it,
sentences.llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: Immorality in the home is like calling for the demon. And Rav Ḥisda said: A palm tree in the home is like calling for the demon. Both of them are harmful, but with a man, we have no concern about it.

sentences.text: וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: בַּתְּחִילָּה, קוֹדֶם שֶׁחָטְאוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל, הָיְתָה שְׁכִינָה שׁוֹרָה עִם כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ מִתְהַלֵּךְ בְּקֶרֶב מַחֲנֶךָ״. כֵּיוָן שֶׁחָטְאוּ נִסְתַּלְּקָה שְׁכִינָה מֵהֶם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא יִרְאֶה בְךָ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר וְשָׁב מֵאַחֲרֶיךָ״.
sentences.human_translation: And Rav Ḥisda says: Initially, before the Jewish people sinned, the Divine Presence resided with each and every one as it is stated: “For the Lord your God walks in the midst of your camp” Once they sinned, the Divine Presence withdrew from them, as it is stated “That He see no unseemly matter in you, and turn away from you”
sentences.llm_translation: And Rav Hisda said: Initially, before the Israelites sinned, the Divine Presence dwelled among each and every one of them, as it is stated: "For the Lord your God walks in the midst of your camp." Once they sinned, the Divine Presence departed from them, as it is stated: "And He will not see any indecency among you and turn away from you."

sentences.text: אָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: כׇּל הָעוֹשֶׂה מִצְוָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — מְקַדַּמְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָלַךְ לְפָנֶיךָ צִדְקֶךָ״. וְכׇל הָעוֹבֵר עֲבֵירָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — מְלַפַּפְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לְיוֹם הַדִּין, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״יִלָּפְתוּ אׇרְחוֹת דַּרְכָּם יַעֲלוּ בַתֹּהוּ וְיֹאבֵדוּ״.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says Rabbi Yonatan says: Anyone who fulfills one mitzva in this world, precedes him and goes before him to the World-to-Come, as it is stated: “And your righteousness shall go before you, And anyone who commits one transgression in this world, it shrouds him and goes before him to the Day of Judgment, as it is stated: “The paths of their way do wind, they go up into the waste, and are lost”
sentences.llm_translation: Said Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said Rabbi Yonatan: Anyone who performs one mitzvah in this world - it precedes him and goes before him to the World to Come, as it is stated: "And your righteousness will go before you." And anyone who commits one transgression in this world - it surrounds him and goes before him on the day of judgment, as it is stated: "Their ways will be tangled in darkness, and they will be lost."

sentences.text: רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: קְשׁוּרָה בּוֹ כְּכֶלֶב, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא שָׁמַע אֵלֶיהָ לִשְׁכַּב אֶצְלָהּ לִהְיוֹת עִמָּהּ״. ״לִשְׁכַּב אֶצְלָהּ״ — בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה, ״לִהְיוֹת עִמָּהּ״ — לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Elazar says: is chained to him like a dog, as it is stated “That he listened not to her, to lie by her, or to be with her” “to lie by her” in this world, “to be with her” to the World-to-Come.
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar says: tied to him like a dog, as it is stated: "And he did not listen to her to lie with her, to be with her." "to lie with her" - in this world, "to be with her" - in the world to come.

sentences.text: תְּנַן הָתָם, שֶׁהָיָה בַּדִּין:
sentences.human_translation: We learned elsewhere as, by right, should have been
sentences.llm_translation: We learned there, that he was in judgment:

sentences.text: וּמָה עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינָהּ מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם, עֵדוּת הָאַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא תִּתְקַיֵּים בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם?
sentences.human_translation: And just as the first testimony which does not forbid her an irrevocable prohibition, is not established with fewer than two the final testimony which forbids her an irrevocable prohibition, is it not logical that it not be established with fewer than two
sentences.llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: "And what is the testimony of the first witness, that you do not prohibit it with a permanent prohibition - it is not upheld with less than two witnesses. The testimony of the last witness, that you do prohibit it with a permanent prohibition - is it not a law that is not upheld with less than two witnesses?"

sentences.text: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְעֵד אֵין בָּהּ״, כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהּ.
sentences.human_translation: the verse states: “And there is no witness against her” any that there is against her
sentences.llm_translation: The Talmud teaches: "And there is no witness in her," anything that has in it.

sentences.text: וְקַל וָחוֹמֶר לְעֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה מֵעַתָּה: וּמָה עֵדוּת הָאַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּעֵד אֶחָד, עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁתִּתְקַיֵּים בְּעֵד אֶחָד?
sentences.human_translation: And now an a fortiori with regard to the first testimony And just as the final testimony which forbids her an irrevocable prohibition, is established with one witness, the first testimony, which does not forbid her an irrevocable prohibition, is it not logical that it should be established with one witness?
sentences.llm_translation: And light and heavy for the testimony of the first from now: And what is the testimony of the latter, that you prohibit it with a perpetual prohibition — it is upheld by one witness, the testimony of the first, that you do not prohibit it with a perpetual prohibition — is it not a law that can be upheld by one witness?

sentences.text: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״, וּלְהַלָּן הוּא אוֹמֵר ״עַל פִּי שְׁנֵי עֵדִים אוֹ עַל פִּי שְׁלֹשָׁה עֵדִים יָקוּם דָּבָר״. מָה ״דָּבָר״ הָאָמוּר לְהַלָּן — עַל פִּי שְׁנַיִם עֵדִים, אַף כָּאן — עַל פִּי שְׁנַיִם.
sentences.human_translation: the verse states: because he has found some unseemly matter [ davar ] about her” and there, it states: “By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter [ davar ] be established” just as “matter” stated there by the mouth of two witnesses, so too here, by the mouth of two
sentences.llm_translation: The Talmud teaches: "For he found in her the nakedness of a matter," and elsewhere it says, "By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established." What is the "matter" mentioned there? By the mouth of two witnesses. So too here - by the mouth of two witnesses.

sentences.text: הַאי מִ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״ נָפְקָא? מִ״בָּהּ״ נָפְקָא: בָּהּ — וְלֹא בְּקִינּוּי, בָּהּ — וְלֹא בִּסְתִירָה מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
sentences.human_translation: this derived from: “Because he has found some unseemly matter about her” It is derived from: against her [ bah ]” With regard to it, but not with regard to warning. With regard to it, but not with regard to seclusion. should have
sentences.llm_translation: This is the case of "if he found in her a matter of nakedness" derived? "In her" derived: in her - and not in betrothal, in her - and not in concealment is required!

sentences.text: הָכִי נָמֵי קָאָמַר: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״בָּהּ״: בָּהּ — וְלֹא בְּקִינּוּי, בָּהּ — וְלֹא בִּסְתִירָה.
sentences.human_translation: That is also what he is saying. The verse states: against her [ bah ],” With regard to it [ bah ], but not with regard to warning. With regard to it, but not with regard to seclusion.
sentences.llm_translation: So did Nami say: The Talmud teaches "in it": in it - and not in a euphemism, in it - and not in a concealment.

sentences.text: וְטוּמְאָה בְּעָלְמָא בְּלֹא קִינּוּי וּבְלֹא סְתִירָה, דְּלָא מְהֵימַן עֵד אֶחָד, מְנָלַן? נֶאֱמַר כָּאן: ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן: ״עַל פִּי שְׁנֵי עֵדִים אוֹ עַל פִּי שְׁלֹשָׁה עֵדִים יָקוּם דָּבָר״. מָה ״דָּבָר״ הָאָמוּר לְהַלָּן — עֵדִים שְׁנַיִם, אַף כָּאן — עֵדִים שְׁנַיִם.
sentences.human_translation: And defilement in general, without warning and without seclusion, from where do we that one witness is not deemed credible? Here it is stated: “Because he has found some unseemly matter about her” and there it is stated: “By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established” just as “matter” stated there two witnesses, so too here, two witnesses.
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: And impurity in general without designation and without contradiction, for not believed one witness, from where? It is stated here: "For he found in her the nakedness of a thing," and it is stated there: "By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established." What is the "matter" mentioned there - two witnesses, so too here - two witnesses.

sentences.text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵי זוֹ הִיא עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה — זוֹ עֵדוּת סְתִירָה, עֵדוּת אַחֲרוֹנָה — זוֹ עֵדוּת טוּמְאָה.
sentences.human_translation: The Sages taught which is the first testimony? This testimony of seclusion. the final testimony? This testimony of defilement.
sentences.llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: What is the first testimony? — This is contradictory testimony. What is the last testimony? — This is testimony of impurity.

text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא — אִם כֵּן, לִיכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא ״לָהּ״ וְלִישְׁתּוֹק, ״יִטַּמָּא״ לְמָה לִי? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.

וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתַב ״לָהּ״, כְּתַב נָמֵי ״יִטַּמָּא״. לְכִדְתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: כָּל פָּרָשָׁה שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרָה וְנִישְׁנֵית, לֹא נִישְׁנֵית אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל דָּבָר שֶׁנִּתְחַדֵּשׁ בָּהּ.
״לְעֹלָם בָּהֶם תַּעֲבֹדוּ״ — רְשׁוּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: חוֹבָה.

מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל — אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתִיב ״לֹא תְחַיֶּה כׇּל נְשָׁמָה״, אִיצְטְרִיךְ נָמֵי לְמִיכְתַּב ״לְעֹלָם בָּהֶם תַּעֲבֹדוּ״, לְמִישְׁרֵי אֶחָד מִכׇּל הָאוּמּוֹת שֶׁבָּא עַל הַכְּנַעֲנִית וְהוֹלִיד מִמֶּנָּה בֵּן, שֶׁאַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לִקְנוֹתוֹ.

דְּתַנְיָא: מִנַּיִן לְאֶחָד מִן הָאוּמּוֹת שֶׁבָּא עַל הַכְּנַעֲנִית וְהוֹלִיד מִמֶּנָּה בֵּן, שֶׁאַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לִקְנוֹתוֹ בְּעֶבֶד, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְגַם מִבְּנֵי הַתּוֹשָׁבִים הַגָּרִים עִמָּכֶם מֵהֶם תִּקְנוּ״.

יָכוֹל אַף הַכְּנַעֲנִי שֶׁבָּא עַל אַחַת מִן הָאוּמּוֹת וְהוֹלִיד מִמֶּנָּה בֵּן, שֶׁאַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לִקְנוֹתוֹ בְּעֶבֶד, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אֲשֶׁר הוֹלִידוּ בְּאַרְצְכֶם״, מִן הַנּוֹלָדִים בְּאַרְצְכֶם, וְלֹא מִן הַגָּרִים בְּאַרְצְכֶם.
וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא מִ״מֵּהֶם תִּקְנוּ״ נָפְקָא, ״לְעֹלָם בָּהֶם תַּעֲבֹדוּ״ לְמָה לִי — לְחוֹבָה.
וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: ״בָּהֶם״ — וְלֹא בְּאַחֵיכֶם.
וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: בְּאַחֵיכֶם — מִסֵּיפָא דִּקְרָא נָפְקָא: ״וּבְאַחֵיכֶם בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל אִישׁ בְּאָחִיו לֹא תִרְדֶּה בוֹ בְּפָרֶךְ״.

וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתִיב ״וּבְאַחֵיכֶם״, כְּתִיב נָמֵי ״בָּהֶם״. לְכִדְתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: כָּל פָּרָשָׁה שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרָה וְנִישְׁנֵית, לֹא נִישְׁנֵית אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל דָּבָר שֶׁנִּתְחַדֵּשׁ בָּהּ.

אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: זְנוּתָא בְּבֵיתָא כִּי קַרְיָא לְשׁוּמְשְׁמָא. וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: תּוּקְפָּא בְּבֵיתָא כִּי קַרְיָא לְשׁוּמְשְׁמָא. אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי בְּאִיתְּתָא, אֲבָל בְּגַבְרָא לֵית לַן בַּהּ.

וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: בַּתְּחִילָּה, קוֹדֶם שֶׁחָטְאוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל, הָיְתָה שְׁכִינָה שׁוֹרָה עִם כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ מִתְהַלֵּךְ בְּקֶרֶב מַחֲנֶךָ״. כֵּיוָן שֶׁחָטְאוּ נִסְתַּלְּקָה שְׁכִינָה מֵהֶם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא יִרְאֶה בְךָ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר וְשָׁב מֵאַחֲרֶיךָ״.

אָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: כׇּל הָעוֹשֶׂה מִצְוָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — מְקַדַּמְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָלַךְ לְפָנֶיךָ צִדְקֶךָ״. וְכׇל הָעוֹבֵר עֲבֵירָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — מְלַפַּפְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לְיוֹם הַדִּין, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״יִלָּפְתוּ אׇרְחוֹת דַּרְכָּם יַעֲלוּ בַתֹּהוּ וְיֹאבֵדוּ״.

רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: קְשׁוּרָה בּוֹ כְּכֶלֶב, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא שָׁמַע אֵלֶיהָ לִשְׁכַּב אֶצְלָהּ לִהְיוֹת עִמָּהּ״. ״לִשְׁכַּב אֶצְלָהּ״ — בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה, ״לִהְיוֹת עִמָּהּ״ — לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא.
תְּנַן הָתָם, שֶׁהָיָה בַּדִּין:

וּמָה עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינָהּ מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם, עֵדוּת הָאַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא תִּתְקַיֵּים בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם?
תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְעֵד אֵין בָּהּ״, כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהּ.

וְקַל וָחוֹמֶר לְעֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה מֵעַתָּה: וּמָה עֵדוּת הָאַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּעֵד אֶחָד, עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁתִּתְקַיֵּים בְּעֵד אֶחָד?

תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״, וּלְהַלָּן הוּא אוֹמֵר ״עַל פִּי שְׁנֵי עֵדִים אוֹ עַל פִּי שְׁלֹשָׁה עֵדִים יָקוּם דָּבָר״. מָה ״דָּבָר״ הָאָמוּר לְהַלָּן — עַל פִּי שְׁנַיִם עֵדִים, אַף כָּאן — עַל פִּי שְׁנַיִם.
הַאי מִ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״ נָפְקָא? מִ״בָּהּ״ נָפְקָא: בָּהּ — וְלֹא בְּקִינּוּי, בָּהּ — וְלֹא בִּסְתִירָה מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
הָכִי נָמֵי קָאָמַר: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״בָּהּ״: בָּהּ — וְלֹא בְּקִינּוּי, בָּהּ — וְלֹא בִּסְתִירָה.

וְטוּמְאָה בְּעָלְמָא בְּלֹא קִינּוּי וּבְלֹא סְתִירָה, דְּלָא מְהֵימַן עֵד אֶחָד, מְנָלַן? נֶאֱמַר כָּאן: ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן: ״עַל פִּי שְׁנֵי עֵדִים אוֹ עַל פִּי שְׁלֹשָׁה עֵדִים יָקוּם דָּבָר״. מָה ״דָּבָר״ הָאָמוּר לְהַלָּן — עֵדִים שְׁנַיִם, אַף כָּאן — עֵדִים שְׁנַיִם.
תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵי זוֹ הִיא עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה — זוֹ עֵדוּת סְתִירָה, עֵדוּת אַחֲרוֹנָה — זוֹ עֵדוּת טוּמְאָה.
וְכַמָּה שִׁיעוּר סְתִירָה? כְּדֵי טוּמְאָה, כְּדֵי בִיאָה, כְּדֵי הַעֲרָאָה.
כְּדֵי הַקָּפַת דֶּקֶל, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי מְזִיגַת הַכּוֹס. רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לִשְׁתּוֹתוֹ.

בֶּן עַזַּאי אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לִצְלוֹת בֵּיצָה. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לְגוֹמְעָהּ. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לִגְמוֹעַ שָׁלֹשׁ בֵּיצִים זוֹ אַחַר זוֹ. רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן יִרְמְיָה אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לִקְשׁוֹר גַּרְדִּי נִימָא.

חָנִין בֶּן פִּנְחָס אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי שֶׁתּוֹשִׁיט יָדָהּ לְתוֹךְ פִּיהָ לִיטּוֹל קֵיסָם. פְּלֵימוֹ אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי שֶׁתּוֹשִׁיט יָדָהּ לַסַּל לִיטּוֹל כִּכָּר. אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין רְאָיָה לַדָּבָר, זֵכֶר לַדָּבָר: ״כִּי בְעַד אִשָּׁה זוֹנָה עַד כִּכַּר לָחֶם״.
וְכׇל הָנֵי לְמָה לִי?
צְרִיכִי, דְּאִי תְּנָא כְּדֵי טוּמְאָה, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: כְּדֵי טוּמְאָתָהּ וְאַרְצוּתָהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כְּדֵי בִיאָה.
וְאִי תְּנָא כְּדֵי בִיאָה, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: כְּדֵי גְּמַר בִּיאָה, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כְּדֵי הַעֲרָאָה.
וְאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן כְּדֵי הַעֲרָאָה, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: כְּדֵי הַעֲרָאָה וְאַרְצוּתָהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כְּדֵי טוּמְאָה. וְכַמָּה כְּדֵי [הַעֲרָאָה] — כְּדֵי הַקָּפַת דֶּקֶל.

וּרְמִינְהִי ״וְנִסְתְּרָה״, וְכַמָּה שִׁיעוּר סְתִירָה לֹא שָׁמַעְנוּ. כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר ״וְהִיא נִטְמָאָה״, הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר — כְּדֵי טוּמְאָה, כְּדֵי בִיאָה, כְּדֵי הַעֲרָאָה, כְּדֵי חֲזָרַת דֶּקֶל, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.

רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי מְזִיגַת הַכּוֹס. בֶּן עַזַּאי אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לִשְׁתּוֹתוֹ. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לִצְלוֹת בֵּיצָה. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לְגוֹמְעָהּ.

קָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתִּין: הַיְינוּ הַקָּפַת דֶּקֶל, הַיְינוּ חֲזָרַת דֶּקֶל. הָתָם אָמַר רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: כְּדֵי הַקָּפַת דֶּקֶל, וּפְלִיג רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר עֲלֵיהּ. הָכָא אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר כְּדֵי חֲזָרַת דֶּקֶל!
אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הַקָּפָה בָּרֶגֶל, חֲזָרָה בָּרוּחַ.
בָּעֵי רַב אָשֵׁי: חֲזָרָה בָּרוּחַ כִּי הֵיכִי דְּאָזֵיל וַהֲדַר אָתֵי, אוֹ דִילְמָא כִּי הֵיכִי דְּאָזֵיל וְאָתֵי וַהֲדַר קָאֵי בְּדוּכְתֵּיהּ. תֵּיקוּ.
הָתָם אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: כְּדֵי מְזִיגַת הַכּוֹס, הָכָא: כְּדֵי חֲזָרַת דֶּקֶל! אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי חַד שִׁיעוּרָא הוּא.

הָתָם אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: כְּדֵי לִשְׁתּוֹתוֹ, הָכָא אָמַר: כְּדֵי מְזִיגַת הַכּוֹס! אֵימָא כְּדֵי לִמְזוֹג וְלִשְׁתּוֹת. וְלֵימָא: אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי חַד שִׁיעוּרָא הוּא! אִם כֵּן, הַיְינוּ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.
הָתָם אָמַר בֶּן עַזַּאי: כְּדֵי לִצְלוֹת בֵּיצָה, הָכָא אָמַר: כְּדֵי לִשְׁתּוֹתוֹ. אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי חַד שִׁיעוּרָא הוּא.

הָתָם אָמַר רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: כְּדֵי לְגוֹמְעָהּ, הָכָא אָמַר: כְּדֵי לִצְלוֹת בֵּיצָה! אֵימָא כְּדֵי לִצְלוֹת בֵּיצָה וּלְגוֹמְעָהּ. וְלֵימָא: אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי חַד שִׁיעוּרָא הוּא! אִם כֵּן, הַיְינוּ בֶּן עַזַּאי.

הָתָם אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא: כְּדֵי לִגְמוֹעַ שָׁלֹשׁ בֵּיצִים זוֹ אַחַר זוֹ, הָכָא אָמַר: כְּדֵי לְגוֹמְעָהּ! לִדְבָרָיו דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא קָאָמַר, דְּקָאָמַר מְשַׁעֲרִין בִּצְלִיאָה וּבִגְמִיעָה: אֵימָא שִׁיעוּר גְּמִיעָה לְחוֹדַהּ כְּדֵי לִגְמֹעַ שָׁלֹשׁ בֵּיצִים זוֹ אַחַר זוֹ, דְּהַיְינוּ צְלִיאָה וּגְמִיעָה.

חָנִין בֶּן פִּנְחָס אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי שֶׁתּוֹשִׁיט יָדָהּ לְתוֹךְ פִּיהָ לִיטּוֹל קֵיסָם. פְּלֵימוֹ אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי שֶׁתּוֹשִׁיט יָדָהּ לַסַּל לִיטּוֹל כִּכָּר. אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין רְאָיָה לַדָּבָר, זֵכֶר לַדָּבָר: ״כִּי בְעַד אִשָּׁה זוֹנָה עַד כִּכַּר לָחֶם״.
וְכׇל הָנֵי לְמָה לִי?
צְרִיכִי, דְּאִי תְּנָא כְּדֵי טוּמְאָה, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: כְּדֵי טוּמְאָתָהּ וְאַרְצוּתָהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כְּדֵי בִיאָה.
וְאִי תְּנָא כְּדֵי בִיאָה, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: כְּדֵי גְּמַר בִּיאָה, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כְּדֵי הַעֲרָאָה.
וְאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן כְּדֵי הַעֲרָאָה, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: כְּדֵי הַעֲרָאָה וְאַרְצוּתָהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כְּדֵי טוּמְאָה. וְכַמָּה כְּדֵי [הַעֲרָאָה] — כְּדֵי הַקָּפַת דֶּקֶל.

וּרְמִינְהִי ״וְנִסְתְּרָה״, וְכַמָּה שִׁיעוּר סְתִירָה לֹא שָׁמַעְנוּ. כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר ״וְהִיא נִטְמָאָה״, הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר — כְּדֵי טוּמְאָה, כְּדֵי בִיאָה, כְּדֵי הַעֲרָאָה, כְּדֵי חֲזָרַת דֶּקֶל, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.

רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי מְזִיגַת הַכּוֹס. בֶּן עַזַּאי אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לִשְׁתּוֹתוֹ. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לִצְלוֹת בֵּיצָה. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לְגוֹמְעָהּ.

קָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתִּין: הַיְינוּ הַקָּפַת דֶּקֶל, הַיְינוּ חֲזָרַת דֶּקֶל. הָתָם אָמַר רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: כְּדֵי הַקָּפַת דֶּקֶל, וּפְלִיג רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר עֲלֵיהּ. הָכָא אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר כְּדֵי חֲזָרַת דֶּקֶל!
אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הַקָּפָה בָּרֶגֶל, חֲזָרָה בָּרוּחַ.
בָּעֵי רַב אָשֵׁי: חֲזָרָה בָּרוּחַ כִּי הֵיכִי דְּאָזֵיל וַהֲדַר אָתֵי, אוֹ דִילְמָא כִּי הֵיכִי דְּאָזֵיל וְאָתֵי וַהֲדַר קָאֵי בְּדוּכְתֵּיהּ. תֵּיקוּ.
הָתָם אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: כְּדֵי מְזִיגַת הַכּוֹס, הָכָא: כְּדֵי חֲזָרַת דֶּקֶל! אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי חַד שִׁיעוּרָא הוּא.

הָתָם אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: כְּדֵי לִשְׁתּוֹתוֹ, הָכָא אָמַר: כְּדֵי מְזִיגַת הַכּוֹס! אֵימָא כְּדֵי לִמְזוֹג וְלִשְׁתּוֹת. וְלֵימָא: אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי חַד שִׁיעוּרָא הוּא! אִם כֵּן, הַיְינוּ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.
הָתָם אָמַר בֶּן עַזַּאי: כְּדֵי לִצְלוֹת בֵּיצָה, הָכָא אָמַר: כְּדֵי לִשְׁתּוֹתוֹ. אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי חַד שִׁיעוּרָא הוּא.

הָתָם אָמַר רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: כְּדֵי לְגוֹמְעָהּ, הָכָא אָמַר: כְּדֵי לִצְלוֹת בֵּיצָה! אֵימָא כְּדֵי לִצְלוֹת בֵּיצָה וּלְגוֹמְעָהּ. וְלֵימָא: אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי חַד שִׁיעוּרָא הוּא! אִם כֵּן, הַיְינוּ בֶּן עַזַּאי.

הָתָם אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא: כְּדֵי לִגְמוֹעַ שָׁלֹשׁ בֵּיצִים זוֹ אַחַר זוֹ, הָכָא אָמַר: כְּדֵי לְגוֹמְעָהּ! לִדְבָרָיו דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא קָאָמַר, דְּקָאָמַר מְשַׁעֲרִין בִּצְלִיאָה וּבִגְמִיעָה: אֵימָא שִׁיעוּר גְּמִיעָה לְחוֹדַהּ כְּדֵי לִגְמֹעַ שָׁלֹשׁ בֵּיצִים זוֹ אַחַר זוֹ, דְּהַיְינוּ צְלִיאָה וּגְמִיעָה.
רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן יִרְמְיָה אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי שֶׁיִּקְשׁוֹר גַּרְדִּי נִימָא. בָּעֵי רַב אָשֵׁי: דִּמְרַחַק, אוֹ דִּמְקָרַב? תֵּיקוּ.
חָנִין בֶּן פִּנְחָס אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי שֶׁתּוֹשִׁיט יָדָהּ לְתוֹךְ פִּיהָ לִיטּוֹל קֵיסָם. בָּעֵי רַב אָשֵׁי: דִּמְהַדַּק אוֹ דְּלָא מְהַדַּק? תֵּיקוּ.
פְּלֵימוֹ אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי שֶׁתּוֹשִׁיט יָדָהּ לַסַּל לִיטּוֹל כִּכָּר. בָּעֵי רַב אָשֵׁי: דִּמְהַדַּק אוֹ דְּלָא מְהַדַּק? בְּחַדְתָּא אוֹ בְּעַתִּיקָא? בְּחַמִּימָא אוֹ בְּקָרִירָא?
llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva - If so, it should have been written "to her" and should have been silenced, "let it be defiled." Why do I need it? Learn from it.

Rabbi Yishmael, since it is written "lah," he wrote "yitama." As it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael. For it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: Any portion that was said and repeated, it was repeated only because of a matter that was newly introduced in it.
"Forever in them you shall serve" - permission, the words of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: obligation.

What is the reason for Rabbi Yishmael's opinion? - Because it is written, "You shall not let any soul live," it was also necessary for it to be written, "You shall serve them forever," to permit marrying one from all the nations that came upon the Canaanite and fathered a child with her, so that you are permitted to acquire him.

It was taught in a Baraita: From where do we derive that one of the nations who came upon the Canaanite and fathered a son from her, that you are permitted to acquire him as a slave? The verse teaches: "And also from the children of the residents who live among you, from them you may acquire."

One might have thought that even a Canaanite who came from one of the nations and fathered a son from among them, that you are permitted to acquire him as a slave. The verse teaches: "Those who were born in your land," from those born in your land, and not from the strangers in your land.
Rabbi Akiva said: "From them they derived, 'You shall serve them forever.' Why do I need it? - For an obligation."
Rabbi Yishmael: "in them" — and not in your brothers.
Rabbi Akiva: "Among your brothers" - derived from the end of the verse: "And among your brothers, the children of Israel, each man shall not rule over his brother with harshness."

Rabbi Yishmael: Through what is written "and in your brothers," it is also written "in them." In accordance with the teaching of the school of Rabbi Yishmael. For it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: Every portion that is stated and repeated, it is repeated only because of a matter that is newly introduced in it.

Rav Ḥisda said: Immorality in the home is like calling for the attendant. And Rav Ḥisda said: A palm tree in the home is like calling for the attendant. Both of them are harmful, but with a man, we have no concern about it.

And Rav Hisda said: Initially, before the Israelites sinned, the Divine Presence dwelled among each and every one of them, as it is stated: "For the Lord your God walks in the midst of your camp." Once they sinned, the Divine Presence departed from them, as it is stated: "And He will not see in you anything unseemly and turn away from you."

Said Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said Rabbi Yonatan: Anyone who performs one mitzvah in this world - it precedes him and goes before him to the World to Come, as it is stated: "And your righteousness will go before you." And anyone who commits one transgression in this world - it surrounds him and goes before him on the day of judgment, as it is stated: "Their ways will be tangled in darkness, and they will be lost."
Rabbi Elazar says: tied to him like a dog, as it is stated: "And he did not listen to her to lie with her, to be with her." "to lie with her" - in this world, "to be with her" - in the world to come.
We learned there, that he was in judgment:

And what is the testimony of the first, that you do not prohibit it with a perpetual prohibition - it is not upheld in less than two. The testimony of the latter, that you do prohibit it with a perpetual prohibition - is it not a law that is not upheld in less than two?
Talmudic text: "Talmud lomar: 've'ed ein bah', kol sheyesh bah."

And light and heavy for the testimony of the first from now: And what is the testimony of the latter, that you prohibit a prohibition forever — it is upheld by one witness, the testimony of the first, that you do not prohibit a prohibition forever — is it not a law that is upheld by one witness?

The Talmud teaches: "For he found in her the nakedness of a matter," and elsewhere it says, "By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established." What is the "matter" mentioned there? By the mouth of two witnesses. So too here - by the mouth of two witnesses.
This is the case of "if he found in her a matter of nakedness" derived? "In her" derived: in her - and not in designation, in her - and not in concealment is required!
So did Naḥmai say: The Talmud teaches "in it": in it - and not by way of euphemism, in it - and not by way of concealment.

Talmudic text: "And impurity in general without designation and without contradiction, for not believed by one witness, from where? It is stated here: 'For he found in her the nakedness of a thing,' and it is stated there: 'By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established.' What is the 'matter' mentioned there — two witnesses, so too here — two witnesses."
The Rabbis taught: What is the first testimony? — This is contradictory testimony. What is the last testimony? — This is testimony of impurity.
And how much is the measure of contradiction? The size of impurity, the size of penetration, the size of visibility.
As much as the bending of a palm branch, the words of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Eliezer says: as much as pouring a cup. Rabbi Yehoshua says: as much as drinking it.

Ben Azzai says: in order to boil an egg. Rabbi Akiva says: in order to roast it. Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says: in order to boil three eggs, one after the other. Rabbi Elazar ben Yirmeya says: in order to tie a garlic peel.

Hanin son of Pinhas says: In order to extend her hand into her mouth to take a date. Paleimo says: In order to extend her hand to the basket to take a loaf. Even though there is no proof for the matter, a remembrance of the matter: "For the price of a prostitute is only a loaf of bread."
And all these, why to me?
I need, for if a Tanna says "the size of impurity," I would say: the size of her impurity and her land, it implies to us the size of entry.
If a Tanna says "the time for intercourse," I would say: "the time for completion of intercourse," it implies to us the time for ejaculation.

And if we were to hear a measurement of the size of a barleycorn, I would say: the size of a barleycorn and its husk, it is teaching us a measurement of the size of impurity. And how much is the measurement of a barleycorn - the size of the cap of a palm tree.

And they asked: "And it was hidden," and how much is the measurement of concealment we have not heard. When he says, "And it became impure," one should say - for the sake of impurity, for the sake of penetration, for the sake of observation, for the sake of the return of the palm tree, the words of Rabbi Eliezer.

Rabbi Yehoshua says: the amount for pouring the cup. Ben Azzai says: the amount for drinking it. Rabbi Akiva says: the amount for roasting an egg. Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says: the amount for swallowing it.

He went up in thought: that is the palm branch, that is the palm shoot. There Rabbi Yishmael said: like the palm branch, and Rabbi Eliezer disagreed with him. Here Rabbi Eliezer said: like the palm shoot!
Abbaye said: The cup in the foot, the wind returned.
Inquiries of Rav Ashei: If the wind returns, how does it go out and then return, or perhaps it goes out and returns while still standing in its place. This matter remains unresolved.
There, said Rabbi Eliezer: for the purpose of mixing the cup, here: for the purpose of palm frond covering! Both are of the same measure.

There, Rabbi Yehoshua said: "In order to drink it." Here, it is said: "In order to pour the cup!" Say instead: "In order to pour and drink." And say: "Both are one measure!" If so, this is Rabbi Eliezer.
There, Ben Azzai said: in order to roast an egg, here it says: in order to boil it. Both are one measure.

There, Rabbi Akiva said: In order to steal it, here it says: In order to roast an egg! I might say: In order to roast an egg and to steal it. And let us say: Both are one measure! If so, this is Ben Azzai.

There, said Rabbi Yehuda ben Betera: In order to swallow three eggs one after the other, here it is said: In order to swallow it! According to the words of Rabbi Akiva, who said that they estimate the size of the egg and the size of the swallow: Say that the measure of the swallow is to swallow three eggs one after the other, which is the size of the swallow and the size of the swallow.
Rabbi Elazar ben Yirmeya says: In order to tie a weasel's tail. Rav Ashi inquired: From a distance, or from up close? The matter remains unresolved.
Hanin son of Pinhas says: In order for her to extend her hand into her mouth to take a spoonful. Rav Ashi asked: Is it ground or not ground? This remains unresolved.
Pleimo says: In order to extend her hand to the basket to take a loaf. Rav Ashi asked: Is it with a new one or an old one? In hot water or in cold water?

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא — אִם כֵּן, לִיכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא ״לָהּ״ וְלִישְׁתּוֹק, ״יִטַּמָּא״ לְמָה לִי? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Akiva If so, let the Merciful One write: for her,” and be silent. Why do I “May he become impure”? Learn from
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva - If so, it should have been written "to her" and should have been silenced, "let it be defiled." Why do I need it? Learn from it.

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתַב ״לָהּ״, כְּתַב נָמֵי ״יִטַּמָּא״. לְכִדְתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: כָּל פָּרָשָׁה שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרָה וְנִישְׁנֵית, לֹא נִישְׁנֵית אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל דָּבָר שֶׁנִּתְחַדֵּשׁ בָּהּ.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Yishmael Since wrote: “For her,” also wrote: “May he become impure,” for as was taught by the school of Rabbi Yishmael. As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Every passage that was stated and repeated, was repeated only for the novel element introduced therein.
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael, since it is written "lah," he wrote "yitama." As it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael. For it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: Any portion that was said and repeated, it was repeated only because of a matter that was newly introduced in it.

sentences.text: ״לְעֹלָם בָּהֶם תַּעֲבֹדוּ״ — רְשׁוּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: חוֹבָה.
sentences.human_translation: “Of them may you take your bondmen forever” optional; the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: mandatory,
sentences.llm_translation: "Forever in them you shall serve" - permission, the words of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: obligation.

sentences.text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל — אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתִיב ״לֹא תְחַיֶּה כׇּל נְשָׁמָה״, אִיצְטְרִיךְ נָמֵי לְמִיכְתַּב ״לְעֹלָם בָּהֶם תַּעֲבֹדוּ״, לְמִישְׁרֵי אֶחָד מִכׇּל הָאוּמּוֹת שֶׁבָּא עַל הַכְּנַעֲנִית וְהוֹלִיד מִמֶּנָּה בֵּן, שֶׁאַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לִקְנוֹתוֹ.

Since it is written “You shall save alive nothing that breathes” it was necessary to write: “Of them may you take your bondmen forever” as well, to permit one from any of the nations who engaged in sexual intercourse with a Canaanite woman and she bore him a child. that you are permitted to purchase
sentences.llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Yishmael's opinion? - Because it is written, "You shall not let any soul live," it was also necessary for it to be written, "You shall serve them forever," to permit marrying one from all the nations that came upon the Canaanite and fathered a child with her, so that you are permitted to acquire him.

sentences.text: דְּתַנְיָא: מִנַּיִן לְאֶחָד מִן הָאוּמּוֹת שֶׁבָּא עַל הַכְּנַעֲנִית וְהוֹלִיד מִמֶּנָּה בֵּן, שֶׁאַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לִקְנוֹתוֹ בְּעֶבֶד, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְגַם מִבְּנֵי הַתּוֹשָׁבִים הַגָּרִים עִמָּכֶם מֵהֶם תִּקְנוּ״.
sentences.human_translation: as it is taught From where that one from the nations who engaged in sexual intercourse with a Canaanite woman, and she bore him a child, that you are permitted to purchase as a slave? The verse states: “Moreover, of the children of the strangers that do sojourn among you, of them may you buy”
sentences.llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: From where do we derive that one of the nations who came upon the Canaanite and fathered a son from her, that you are permitted to acquire him as a slave? The verse teaches: "And also from the children of the residents who live among you, from them you may acquire."

sentences.text: יָכוֹל אַף הַכְּנַעֲנִי שֶׁבָּא עַל אַחַת מִן הָאוּמּוֹת וְהוֹלִיד מִמֶּנָּה בֵּן, שֶׁאַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לִקְנוֹתוֹ בְּעֶבֶד, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אֲשֶׁר הוֹלִידוּ בְּאַרְצְכֶם״, מִן הַנּוֹלָדִים בְּאַרְצְכֶם, וְלֹא מִן הַגָּרִים בְּאַרְצְכֶם.
sentences.human_translation: might even a Canaanite who engaged in sexual intercourse with a woman from the nations and she bore him a child, that you are permitted to purchase as a slave, the verse states: “Which they have given birth to in your land,” from the born in your land but not from the reside in your land,
sentences.llm_translation: One might have thought that even a Canaanite who came from one of the nations and fathered a son from among them, that you are permitted to acquire him as a slave. The verse teaches: "Those who were born in your land," from those born in your land, and not from the strangers in your land.

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא מִ״מֵּהֶם תִּקְנוּ״ נָפְקָא, ״לְעֹלָם בָּהֶם תַּעֲבֹדוּ״ לְמָה לִי — לְחוֹבָה.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Akiva derives from “Of them may you buy.” why do I “Of them may you take your bondmen forever” to mandatory
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva said: "From them they derived, 'You shall serve them forever.' Why do I need it? - For an obligation."

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: ״בָּהֶם״ — וְלֹא בְּאַחֵיכֶם.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Yishmael “of them,” but not of your brethren,
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael: "in them" — and not in your brothers.

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: בְּאַחֵיכֶם — מִסֵּיפָא דִּקְרָא נָפְקָא: ״וּבְאַחֵיכֶם בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל אִישׁ בְּאָחִיו לֹא תִרְדֶּה בוֹ בְּפָרֶךְ״.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Akiva your brethren is derived from the latter of the verse, “But over your brethren the children of Israel you shall not rule, one over another, with rigor”
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva: "Among your brothers" - derived from the end of the verse: "And among your brothers, the children of Israel, each man shall not rule over his brother with harshness."

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתִיב ״וּבְאַחֵיכֶם״, כְּתִיב נָמֵי ״בָּהֶם״. לְכִדְתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: כָּל פָּרָשָׁה שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרָה וְנִישְׁנֵית, לֹא נִישְׁנֵית אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל דָּבָר שֶׁנִּתְחַדֵּשׁ בָּהּ.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Yishmael since it is written: “But over your brethren,” it also writes “of them,” because of that was taught by the school of Rabbi Yishmael. As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Every passage that was stated and repeated, was repeated only for the novel element introduced therein.
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael: Through what is written "and in your brothers," it is also written "in them." In accordance with the teaching of the school of Rabbi Yishmael. For it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: Every portion that is stated and repeated, it is repeated only because of a matter that is newly introduced in it.

sentences.text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: זְנוּתָא בְּבֵיתָא כִּי קַרְיָא לְשׁוּמְשְׁמָא. וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: תּוּקְפָּא בְּבֵיתָא כִּי קַרְיָא לְשׁוּמְשְׁמָא. אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי בְּאִיתְּתָא, אֲבָל בְּגַבְרָא לֵית לַן בַּהּ.
sentences.human_translation: Rav Ḥisda says: Licentious in a home like a worm [ karya ] to sesame [ shumeshema ]. And Rav Ḥisda says: Anger in a home like a worm to sesame. this and that, with regard to the woman but with regard to the man, we do not have with regard to it,
sentences.llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: Immorality in the home is like calling for the attendant. And Rav Ḥisda said: A palm tree in the home is like calling for the attendant. Both of them are harmful, but with a man, we have no concern about it.

sentences.text: וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: בַּתְּחִילָּה, קוֹדֶם שֶׁחָטְאוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל, הָיְתָה שְׁכִינָה שׁוֹרָה עִם כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ מִתְהַלֵּךְ בְּקֶרֶב מַחֲנֶךָ״. כֵּיוָן שֶׁחָטְאוּ נִסְתַּלְּקָה שְׁכִינָה מֵהֶם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא יִרְאֶה בְךָ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר וְשָׁב מֵאַחֲרֶיךָ״.
sentences.human_translation: And Rav Ḥisda says: Initially, before the Jewish people sinned, the Divine Presence resided with each and every one as it is stated: “For the Lord your God walks in the midst of your camp” Once they sinned, the Divine Presence withdrew from them, as it is stated “That He see no unseemly matter in you, and turn away from you”
sentences.llm_translation: And Rav Hisda said: Initially, before the Israelites sinned, the Divine Presence dwelled among each and every one of them, as it is stated: "For the Lord your God walks in the midst of your camp." Once they sinned, the Divine Presence departed from them, as it is stated: "And He will not see in you anything unseemly and turn away from you."

sentences.text: אָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: כׇּל הָעוֹשֶׂה מִצְוָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — מְקַדַּמְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָלַךְ לְפָנֶיךָ צִדְקֶךָ״. וְכׇל הָעוֹבֵר עֲבֵירָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — מְלַפַּפְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לְיוֹם הַדִּין, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״יִלָּפְתוּ אׇרְחוֹת דַּרְכָּם יַעֲלוּ בַתֹּהוּ וְיֹאבֵדוּ״.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says Rabbi Yonatan says: Anyone who fulfills one mitzva in this world, precedes him and goes before him to the World-to-Come, as it is stated: “And your righteousness shall go before you, And anyone who commits one transgression in this world, it shrouds him and goes before him to the Day of Judgment, as it is stated: “The paths of their way do wind, they go up into the waste, and are lost”
sentences.llm_translation: Said Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said Rabbi Yonatan: Anyone who performs one mitzvah in this world - it precedes him and goes before him to the World to Come, as it is stated: "And your righteousness will go before you." And anyone who commits one transgression in this world - it surrounds him and goes before him on the day of judgment, as it is stated: "Their ways will be tangled in darkness, and they will be lost."

sentences.text: רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: קְשׁוּרָה בּוֹ כְּכֶלֶב, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא שָׁמַע אֵלֶיהָ לִשְׁכַּב אֶצְלָהּ לִהְיוֹת עִמָּהּ״. ״לִשְׁכַּב אֶצְלָהּ״ — בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה, ״לִהְיוֹת עִמָּהּ״ — לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Elazar says: is chained to him like a dog, as it is stated “That he listened not to her, to lie by her, or to be with her” “to lie by her” in this world, “to be with her” to the World-to-Come.
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar says: tied to him like a dog, as it is stated: "And he did not listen to her to lie with her, to be with her." "to lie with her" - in this world, "to be with her" - in the world to come.

sentences.text: תְּנַן הָתָם, שֶׁהָיָה בַּדִּין:
sentences.human_translation: We learned elsewhere as, by right, should have been
sentences.llm_translation: We learned there, that he was in judgment:

sentences.text: וּמָה עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינָהּ מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם, עֵדוּת הָאַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא תִּתְקַיֵּים בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם?
sentences.human_translation: And just as the first testimony which does not forbid her an irrevocable prohibition, is not established with fewer than two the final testimony which forbids her an irrevocable prohibition, is it not logical that it not be established with fewer than two
sentences.llm_translation: And what is the testimony of the first, that you do not prohibit it with a perpetual prohibition - it is not upheld in less than two. The testimony of the latter, that you do prohibit it with a perpetual prohibition - is it not a law that is not upheld in less than two?

sentences.text: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְעֵד אֵין בָּהּ״, כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהּ.
sentences.human_translation: the verse states: “And there is no witness against her” any that there is against her
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Talmud lomar: 've'ed ein bah', kol sheyesh bah."

sentences.text: וְקַל וָחוֹמֶר לְעֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה מֵעַתָּה: וּמָה עֵדוּת הָאַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּעֵד אֶחָד, עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁתִּתְקַיֵּים בְּעֵד אֶחָד?
sentences.human_translation: And now an a fortiori with regard to the first testimony And just as the final testimony which forbids her an irrevocable prohibition, is established with one witness, the first testimony, which does not forbid her an irrevocable prohibition, is it not logical that it should be established with one witness?
sentences.llm_translation: And light and heavy for the testimony of the first from now: And what is the testimony of the latter, that you prohibit a prohibition forever — it is upheld by one witness, the testimony of the first, that you do not prohibit a prohibition forever — is it not a law that is upheld by one witness?

sentences.text: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״, וּלְהַלָּן הוּא אוֹמֵר ״עַל פִּי שְׁנֵי עֵדִים אוֹ עַל פִּי שְׁלֹשָׁה עֵדִים יָקוּם דָּבָר״. מָה ״דָּבָר״ הָאָמוּר לְהַלָּן — עַל פִּי שְׁנַיִם עֵדִים, אַף כָּאן — עַל פִּי שְׁנַיִם.
sentences.human_translation: the verse states: because he has found some unseemly matter [ davar ] about her” and there, it states: “By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter [ davar ] be established” just as “matter” stated there by the mouth of two witnesses, so too here, by the mouth of two
sentences.llm_translation: The Talmud teaches: "For he found in her the nakedness of a matter," and elsewhere it says, "By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established." What is the "matter" mentioned there? By the mouth of two witnesses. So too here - by the mouth of two witnesses.

sentences.text: הַאי מִ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״ נָפְקָא? מִ״בָּהּ״ נָפְקָא: בָּהּ — וְלֹא בְּקִינּוּי, בָּהּ — וְלֹא בִּסְתִירָה מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
sentences.human_translation: this derived from: “Because he has found some unseemly matter about her” It is derived from: against her [ bah ]” With regard to it, but not with regard to warning. With regard to it, but not with regard to seclusion. should have
sentences.llm_translation: This is the case of "if he found in her a matter of nakedness" derived? "In her" derived: in her - and not in designation, in her - and not in concealment is required!

sentences.text: הָכִי נָמֵי קָאָמַר: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״בָּהּ״: בָּהּ — וְלֹא בְּקִינּוּי, בָּהּ — וְלֹא בִּסְתִירָה.
sentences.human_translation: That is also what he is saying. The verse states: against her [ bah ],” With regard to it [ bah ], but not with regard to warning. With regard to it, but not with regard to seclusion.
sentences.llm_translation: So did Naḥmai say: The Talmud teaches "in it": in it - and not by way of euphemism, in it - and not by way of concealment.

sentences.text: וְטוּמְאָה בְּעָלְמָא בְּלֹא קִינּוּי וּבְלֹא סְתִירָה, דְּלָא מְהֵימַן עֵד אֶחָד, מְנָלַן? נֶאֱמַר כָּאן: ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן: ״עַל פִּי שְׁנֵי עֵדִים אוֹ עַל פִּי שְׁלֹשָׁה עֵדִים יָקוּם דָּבָר״. מָה ״דָּבָר״ הָאָמוּר לְהַלָּן — עֵדִים שְׁנַיִם, אַף כָּאן — עֵדִים שְׁנַיִם.
sentences.human_translation: And defilement in general, without warning and without seclusion, from where do we that one witness is not deemed credible? Here it is stated: “Because he has found some unseemly matter about her” and there it is stated: “By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established” just as “matter” stated there two witnesses, so too here, two witnesses.
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And impurity in general without designation and without contradiction, for not believed by one witness, from where? It is stated here: 'For he found in her the nakedness of a thing,' and it is stated there: 'By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established.' What is the 'matter' mentioned there — two witnesses, so too here — two witnesses."

sentences.text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵי זוֹ הִיא עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה — זוֹ עֵדוּת סְתִירָה, עֵדוּת אַחֲרוֹנָה — זוֹ עֵדוּת טוּמְאָה.
sentences.human_translation: The Sages taught which is the first testimony? This testimony of seclusion. the final testimony? This testimony of defilement.
sentences.llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: What is the first testimony? — This is contradictory testimony. What is the last testimony? — This is testimony of impurity.

sentences.text: וְכַמָּה שִׁיעוּר סְתִירָה? כְּדֵי טוּמְאָה, כְּדֵי בִיאָה, כְּדֵי הַעֲרָאָה.
sentences.human_translation: And what is the measure of seclusion, equivalent defilement, equivalent intercourse, equivalent initial stage of intercourse.
sentences.llm_translation: And how much is the measure of contradiction? The size of impurity, the size of penetration, the size of visibility.

sentences.text: כְּדֵי הַקָּפַת דֶּקֶל, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי מְזִיגַת הַכּוֹס. רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי לִשְׁתּוֹתוֹ.

text: יֵשׁ לָהּ עֵדִים בִּמְדִינַת הַיָּם!
לָא שְׁכִיחָא.

מַתְנִי׳ כֵּיצַד עוֹשֶׂה לָהּ? מוֹלִיכָהּ לְבֵית דִּין שֶׁבְּאוֹתוֹ מָקוֹם, וּמוֹסְרִין לוֹ שְׁנֵי תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים, שֶׁמָּא יָבֹא עָלֶיהָ בַּדֶּרֶךְ. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בַּעְלָהּ נֶאֱמָן עָלֶיהָ.

גְּמָ׳ תְּרֵי וְאִיהוּ — הָא תְּלָתָא. לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְרַב. דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בָּעִיר, אֲבָל בַּדֶּרֶךְ — עַד דְּאִיכָּא שְׁלֹשָׁה, שֶׁמָּא יִצְטָרֵךְ אֶחָד מֵהֶן לִנְקָבָיו, וְנִמְצָא אֶחָד מֵהֶן מִתְיַיחֵד עִם הָעֶרְוָה.
לָא: הָכָא הַיְינוּ טַעְמָא כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלִיהְווֹ עֲלֵיהּ סָהֲדִי.

תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים — אִין, כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא — לָא. לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְאִידַּךְ דְּרַב, דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא כְּשֵׁרִין, אֲבָל פְּרוּצִין, אֲפִילּוּ עֲשָׂרָה נָמֵי לָא. מַעֲשֶׂה הָיָה וְהוֹצִיאוּהָ עֲשָׂרָה בְּמִטָּה.
לָא, הָכָא הַיְינוּ טַעְמָא — דְּיָדְעִי לְאַתְרוֹיֵי בֵּיהּ.

רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בַּעְלָהּ וְכוּ׳. תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר, בַּעְלָהּ נֶאֱמָן מִקַּל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה נִדָּה שֶׁהִיא בְּכָרֵת — בַּעְלָהּ נֶאֱמָן עָלֶיהָ, סוֹטָה שֶׁהִיא בְּלָאו — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?!

גְּמָ׳ תְּרֵי וְאִיהוּ — הָא תְּלָתָא. לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְרַב. דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בָּעִיר, אֲבָל בַּדֶּרֶךְ — עַד דְּאִיכָּא שְׁלֹשָׁה, שֶׁמָּא יִצְטָרֵךְ אֶחָד מֵהֶן לִנְקָבָיו, וְנִמְצָא אֶחָד מֵהֶן מִתְיַיחֵד עִם הָעֶרְוָה.
לָא: הָכָא הַיְינוּ טַעְמָא כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלִיהְווֹ עֲלֵיהּ סָהֲדִי.

תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים — אִין, כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא — לָא. לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְאִידַּךְ דְּרַב, דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא כְּשֵׁרִין, אֲבָל פְּרוּצִין, אֲפִילּוּ עֲשָׂרָה נָמֵי לָא. מַעֲשֶׂה הָיָה וְהוֹצִיאוּהָ עֲשָׂרָה בְּמִטָּה.
לָא, הָכָא הַיְינוּ טַעְמָא — דְּיָדְעִי לְאַתְרוֹיֵי בֵּיהּ.

רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בַּעְלָהּ וְכוּ׳. תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר, בַּעְלָהּ נֶאֱמָן מִקַּל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה נִדָּה שֶׁהִיא בְּכָרֵת — בַּעְלָהּ נֶאֱמָן עָלֶיהָ, סוֹטָה שֶׁהִיא בְּלָאו — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?!
וְרַבָּנַן, הִיא הַנּוֹתֶנֶת: נִדָּה דְּכָרֵת — חֲמִירָא לֵיהּ וּמְהֵימַן. סוֹטָה דְּלָאו — לָא חֲמִירָא לֵיהּ, וְלָא מְהֵימַן.

וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מִקַּל וָחוֹמֶר מַיְיתֵי לַהּ? וְהָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מִקְּרָאֵי מַיְיתֵי לַהּ! דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְהֵבִיא הָאִישׁ אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ אֶל הַכֹּהֵן״. מִן הַתּוֹרָה הָאִישׁ מֵבִיא אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ, אֲבָל אָמְרוּ חֲכָמִים: מוֹסְרִין לוֹ שְׁנֵי תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים, שֶׁמָּא יָבֹא עָלֶיהָ בַּדֶּרֶךְ.
רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר, בַּעְלָהּ נֶאֱמָן עָלֶיהָ מִקַּל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה נִדָּה שֶׁהִיא בְּכָרֵת — בַּעְלָהּ נֶאֱמָן עָלֶיהָ, סוֹטָה שֶׁהִיא בְּלָאו — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?!
אָמְרוּ לוֹ: לֹא, אִם אָמַרְתָּ בְּנִדָּה — שֶׁכֵּן יֵשׁ לָהּ הֶיתֵּר, תֹּאמַר בְּסוֹטָה — שֶׁאֵין לָהּ הֶיתֵּר, וְאוֹמֵר: ״מַיִם גְּנוּבִים יִמְתָּקוּ וְגוֹ׳״.
רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: מִן הַתּוֹרָה הָאִישׁ מֵבִיא אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ אֶל הַכֹּהֵן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהֵבִיא הָאִישׁ אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ״!
אֲמַר לְהוּ קַל וָחוֹמֶר בְּרֵישָׁא וּפַרְכוּהּ, וַהֲדַר אָמַר לְהוּ קְרָא.
רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הַיְינוּ תַּנָּא קַמָּא! אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ ״אֲבָל אָמְרוּ״.
מַתְנִי׳ הָיוּ מַעֲלִין אוֹתָהּ לְבֵית דִּין הַגָּדוֹל שֶׁבִּירוּשָׁלַיִם, וּמְאַיְּימִין עָלֶיהָ כְּדֶרֶךְ שֶׁמְּאַיְּימִין עַל עֵדֵי נְפָשׁוֹת.
וְאוֹמֵר לָהּ: בִּתִּי, הַרְבֵּה יַיִן עוֹשֶׂה, הַרְבֵּה שְׂחוֹק עוֹשֶׂה, הַרְבֵּה יַלְדוּת עוֹשָׂה, הַרְבֵּה שְׁכֵנִים הָרָעִים עוֹשִׂין.
עֲשִׂי לִשְׁמוֹ הַגָּדוֹל שֶׁנִּכְתַּב בִּקְדוּשָּׁה שֶׁלֹּא יִמָּחֶה עַל הַמַּיִם. וְאוֹמֵר לְפָנֶיהָ דְּבָרִים שֶׁאֵינָם כְּדַי לְשׁוֹמְעָן, הִיא וְכׇל מִשְׁפַּחַת בֵּית אָבִיהָ.
אִם אָמְרָה ״טְמֵאָה אֲנִי״ — שׁוֹבֶרֶת כְּתוּבָּתָהּ וְיוֹצֵאת.
וְאִם אָמְרָה ״טְהוֹרָה אֲנִי״ — מַעֲלִין אוֹתָהּ לְשַׁעַר הַמִּזְרָח שֶׁעַל פֶּתַח שַׁעַר נִקָּנוֹר, שֶׁשָּׁם מַשְׁקִין אֶת הַסּוֹטוֹת, וּמְטַהֲרִין אֶת הַיּוֹלְדוֹת, וּמְטַהֲרִין אֶת הַמְצוֹרָעִין.

וְכֹהֵן אוֹחֵז בִּבְגָדֶיהָ. אִם נִקְרְעוּ — נִקְרְעוּ. וְאִם נִפְרְמוּ — נִפְרְמוּ. עַד שֶׁהוּא מְגַלֶּה אֶת לִבָּהּ. וְסוֹתֵר אֶת שְׂעָרָהּ. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אִם הָיָה לִבָּהּ נָאֶה — לֹא הָיָה מְגַלֵּהוּ, וְאִם הָיָה שְׂעָרָהּ נָאֶה — לֹא הָיָה סוֹתֵר.
הָיְתָה מִתְכַּסָּה בִּלְבָנִים — מְכַסֶּהָ בִּשְׁחוֹרִים. הָיָה עָלֶיהָ כְּלֵי זָהָב
וְקַטְלֵיאוֹת, נְזָמִים וְטַבָּעוֹת — מַעֲבִירִין מִמֶּנָּה, כְּדֵי לְנַוְּולָהּ. וְאַחַר כָּךְ מֵבִיא חֶבֶל מִצְרִי וְקוֹשְׁרוֹ לְמַעְלָה מִדַּדֶּיהָ,

וְכׇל הָרוֹצֶה לִרְאוֹת בָּא לִרְאוֹת, חוּץ מֵעֲבָדֶיהָ וְשִׁפְחוֹתֶיהָ, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁלִּבָּהּ גַּס בָּהֶן. וְכׇל הַנָּשִׁים מוּתָּרוֹת לִרְאוֹתָהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְנִוַּסְּרוּ כׇּל הַנָּשִׁים וְלֹא תַעֲשֶׂינָה כְּזִמַּתְכֶנָה״.

גְּמָ׳ מְנָהָנֵי מִילֵּי? אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר גַּמָּדָא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: אָתְיָא ״תּוֹרָה״ ״תּוֹרָה״. כְּתִיב הָכָא: ״וְעָשָׂה לָהּ הַכֹּהֵן אֵת כׇּל הַתּוֹרָה״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם: ״עַל פִּי הַתּוֹרָה אֲשֶׁר יוֹרוּךָ״, מָה לְהַלָּן בְּשִׁבְעִים וְאֶחָד — אַף כָּאן בְּשִׁבְעִים וְאֶחָד.

וּמְאַיְּימִין עָלֶיהָ וְכוּ׳. וּרְמִינְהוּ: כְּדֶרֶךְ שֶׁמְּאַיְּימִין עָלֶיהָ שֶׁלֹּא תִּשְׁתֶּה כָּךְ מְאַיְּימִין עָלֶיהָ שֶׁתִּשְׁתֶּה. אוֹמְרִים לָהּ: בִּתִּי, אִם בָּרוּר לָךְ הַדָּבָר שֶׁטְּהוֹרָה אַתְּ עִמְדִי עַל בּוּרְיִיךְ, וּשְׁתִי. לְפִי שֶׁאֵין מַיִם הַמָּרִים דּוֹמִין אֶלָּא לְסַם יָבֵשׁ שֶׁמּוּנָּח עַל בָּשָׂר חַי. אִם יֵשׁ שָׁם מַכָּה — מְחַלְחֵל וְיוֹרֵד, אֵין שָׁם מַכָּה — אֵינוֹ מוֹעִיל כְּלוּם.
לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן — קוֹדֶם שֶׁנִּמְחֲקָה מְגִילָּה. כָּאן — לְאַחַר שֶׁנִּמְחֲקָה מְגִילָּה.

וְאוֹמֵר לְפָנֶיהָ וְכוּ׳. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אוֹמֵר לְפָנֶיהָ דְּבָרִים שֶׁל הַגָּדָה, וּמַעֲשִׂים שֶׁאֵירְעוּ בִּכְתוּבִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים, כְּגוֹן: ״אֲשֶׁר חֲכָמִים יַגִּידוּ וְלֹא כִחֲדוּ מֵאֲבוֹתָם״.

יְהוּדָה הוֹדָה וְלֹא בּוֹשׁ, מֶה הָיָה סוֹפוֹ — נָחַל חַיֵּי הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא. רְאוּבֵן הוֹדָה וְלֹא בּוֹשׁ, מֶה הָיָה סוֹפוֹ — נָחַל חַיֵּי הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא. וּמָה שְׂכָרָן? מָה שְׂכָרָן?! כִּדְקָא אָמְרִינַן! אֶלָּא: מָה שְׂכָרָן בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה, ״לָהֶם לְבַדָּם נִתְּנָה הָאָרֶץ וְלֹא עָבַר זָר בְּתוֹכָם״.
בִּשְׁלָמָא בִּיהוּדָה אַשְׁכְּחַן דְּאוֹדִי, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיַּכֵּר יְהוּדָה וַיֹּאמֶר צָדְקָה מִמֶּנִּי״, אֶלָּא רְאוּבֵן מְנָלַן דְּאוֹדִי?
דְּאָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״יְחִי רְאוּבֵן וְאַל יָמֹת״, ״וְזֹאת לִיהוּדָה״?

כׇּל אוֹתָן שָׁנִים שֶׁהָיוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל בַּמִּדְבָּר, הָיוּ עַצְמוֹתָיו שֶׁל יְהוּדָה מְגוּלְגָּלִין בָּאָרוֹן, עַד שֶׁעָמַד מֹשֶׁה וּבִקֵּשׁ עָלָיו רַחֲמִים. אָמַר לְפָנָיו: רִבּוֹנוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם, מִי גָּרַם לִרְאוּבֵן שֶׁהוֹדָה — יְהוּדָה: ״וְזֹאת לִיהוּדָה״?!

מִיָּד: ״שְׁמַע ה׳ קוֹל יְהוּדָה״, עָל אֵיבְרֵיהּ לְשָׁפָא. וְלָא הֲוָה קָא מְעַיְּילִין לֵיהּ לִמְתִיבְתָּא דִרְקִיעָא, ״וְאֶל עַמּוֹ תְּבִיאֶנּוּ״. וְלָא הֲוָה קָא יָדַע מִשְׁקַל וּמִטְרַח בִּשְׁמַעְתָּא בַּהֲדֵי רַבָּנַן, ״יָדָיו רָב לוֹ״. לָא הֲוָה קָא סָלְקָא לֵיהּ שְׁמַעְתָּא אַלִּיבָּא דְהִילְכְתָא, ״וְעֵזֶר מִצָּרָיו תִּהְיֶה״.

בִּשְׁלָמָא יְהוּדָה דְּאוֹדִי, כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלֹא תִּישָּׂרֵף תָּמָר. אֶלָּא רְאוּבֵן, לְמָה לֵיהּ דְּאוֹדִי? וְהָאָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: חֲצִיף עֲלַי דִּמְפָרֵיט חֶטְאֵיהּ? כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלָא לִיחַשְׁדוּ אֲחוֹהִי.
אִם אָמְרָה ״טְמֵאָה אֲנִי״ וְכוּ׳. שָׁמְעַתְּ מִינַּהּ כּוֹתְבִין שׁוֹבָר.
אָמַר אַבָּיֵי, תְּנִי: ״מְקָרַעַת״. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: וְהָא ״שׁוֹבֶרֶת״ קָתָנֵי! אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: בִּמְקוֹם שֶׁאֵין כּוֹתְבִין כְּתוּבָּה עָסְקִינַן.
וְאִם אָמְרָה ״טְהוֹרָה אֲנִי״ מַעֲלִין אוֹתָהּ לְשַׁעֲרֵי מִזְרָח. מַעֲלִין אוֹתָהּ?!

The Mishnah teaches: How does one act towards her? He brings her to the court in that place, and they appoint two Torah scholars to accompany him, lest he come upon her on the way. Rabbi Yehudah says: Her husband is trusted regarding her.

Gemara: "Gemar trei ve'ihu — ha treita. Leima mesayaya lei l'Rav. D'amar Rav Yehuda amar Rav: Lo shanu ela ba'ir, aval baderech — ad d'ikka shlosha, shema yitztarech echad mehen lin'kavav, v'nimtza echad mehen mit'yached im ha'ervah." Translation: "The Gemara concludes: 'Two and he — that makes three.' Let us say that this supports Rav's opinion. For Rav Yehuda said in the name of Rav: They only made this distinction in a city, but on the road — until there are three men, lest one of them need to relieve himself, and it turns out that one of them is alone with a woman."
Not here, this is the reason, as how that they should be witnesses upon it.

Students of the sages — yes, everyone else — no. Let us say it supports the other opinion of Rav, for Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: They only stated this regarding kosher items, but regarding non-kosher items, even ten people do not make it permissible. There was an incident, and they brought it out with ten people in a bed.
No, here this is the reason - that he knows his place.

Rabbi Yehuda says: "Her husband, etc." It was taught: Rabbi Yehuda says, "Her husband is believed from a kal vachomer: and if a niddah, which is punishable by karet - her husband is believed regarding her, a sotah, which is only a prohibition - all the more so?!"
The Sages, that is the one who gives: a menstruating woman who is subject to karet — stringent for her and trustworthy. A sotah who is not so — neither stringent for her, nor trustworthy.

Talmudic text: And Rabbi Yehuda from a fortiori argument brings it to her? But Rabbi Yehuda brings it from scriptural verses! For it was taught: "And the man shall bring his wife to the kohen." From the Torah, the man brings his wife, but the sages said: They appoint for him two Torah scholars, lest he come upon her on the way.

Rabbi Yosei says, her husband is believed regarding her from a fortiori argument: And what is the case of a woman who is liable to karet - her husband is believed regarding her, how much more so a sotah who is only in a negative prohibition - is it not all the more so?!

They said to him: No, if you said regarding a woman in a state of niddah - that she has a permissible aspect, say regarding a sotah - that she does not have a permissible aspect, and say, "Stolen waters are sweet, etc."
Rabbi Yehuda says: From the Torah, a man brings his wife to the Kohen, as it is stated: "And the man shall bring his wife"!
He said to them a fortiori at the beginning and its refutation, and then he said to them a verse.
Rabbi Yehuda said, that is the first teaching! There is a difference between them, "but they said."
The Mishnah teaches: They would bring her to the Great Court in Jerusalem, and they would intimidate her as they intimidate witnesses in capital cases.
And he says to her: My daughter, much wine makes, much laughter makes, much childishness makes, many evil neighbors make.

Do for His great Name that is written in holiness that it should not be erased upon the water. And he says before her words that are not enough to hear, she and all the household of her father's house.
If she said, "I am impure" - she breaks her marriage contract and leaves.

"And if she said, 'I am pure' — they bring her up to the gate of the east that is at the entrance of the gate of Nicanor, where they give the sotahs to drink, and purify the women after childbirth, and purify the lepers."

A priest holds onto her garments. If they tore - they tore. And if they became untangled - they became untangled. Until he reveals her heart. And he undoes her hair. Rabbi Yehuda says: If her heart was beautiful - he would not reveal it, and if her hair was beautiful - he would not undo it.
She was covered in white - he covers her in black. There were golden vessels upon her.
"and katleiota, nezamim and tabaot — remove from it, in order to beautify it. And afterwards brings an Egyptian rope and ties it above its sides,"

Talmudic text: And anyone who wishes to see may come to see, except for her maidservants and handmaidens, because her heart is haughty towards them. And all women are permitted to see her, as it is stated: "And all the women will be modest and not act haughtily like her."

Gemara: What is the meaning of "matters of delight"? Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Gamda said in the name of Rabbi Yosei bar Rabbi Ḥanina: It comes to teach "Torah, Torah." It is written here: "And the kohen shall make for her all of the Torah," and it is written there: "According to the Torah that they will teach you." Just as there, it is seventy-one — so too here, it is seventy-one.

"And they threaten her, etc." And they raised a dilemma: Just as when they threaten her not to drink, so too when they threaten her to drink. They say to her: 'My daughter, if the matter is clear to you that it is a pregnancy, stand on your pit and drink.' Because bitter waters only resemble dry poison placed on living flesh. If there is a wound there - it will swell and descend, if there is no wound there - it will not help at all.
Not difficult: here - before the Megillah was erased. Here - after the Megillah was erased.

And he says before her, etc. The Rabbis taught: He says before her words of Aggadah, and events that occurred in the earlier Scriptures, such as: "Which the wise will tell and not hide from their fathers."

Judah confesses and is not ashamed, what was his end? — He will inherit the life of the world to come. Reuben confesses and is not ashamed, what was his end? — He will inherit the life of the world to come. And what is their reward? What is their reward?! As it is said! Rather: What is their reward in this world, "To them alone the land was given, and no stranger passed among them."
In Shilma in Judea, I found a teaching of Udi, as it is written: "And Judah acknowledged and said, 'She is more righteous than I.'" But where is Reuben found in this teaching?
The text reads: Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: What is the meaning of the verse "Let Reuben live and not die," "and this for Judah"?

All those years that Israel was in the wilderness, the bones of Judah were rolling in the Ark, until Moses stood and sought mercy for him. He said before Him: Master of the Universe, who caused Reuben to confess? — Judah: "And this is for Judah"?!

Immediately: "Hear, O Lord, the voice of Judah," upon his limbs to shatter. And they were not leading him to the bed of the firmament, "And to his people you shall bring him." And he did not know the weight and burden in the hearing in the presence of the sages, "His hands shall be sufficient for him." The hearing did not ascend to him on the path that he walked, "And a help against his adversaries shall he be."

In truth, Judah of Odai, how is it that the date palm does not burn? Rather, Reuben, why is it that it does not burn? And Rav Sheshet said: Is it not enough for him that he commits his sins secretly? So that his brothers should not be suspected.
If she said, "I am impure," etc. We learn from her kind, they write "Shovar."
Abaye said, it was taught: "tearing." Rava said to him: But doesn't it teach "breaking"! Rather, Rava said: We are dealing with a case where one does not write a document.
And if she said, "I am pure," we bring her up to the eastern gates. Bring her up?!
