רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בְּנוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי אוֹמֵר: כְּקָטָן הַמַּקְרֶא אֶת הַלֵּל, וְהֵן עוֹנִין אַחֲרָיו כׇּל מָה שֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר. מֹשֶׁה אָמַר ״אָשִׁירָה לַה׳״ וְהֵן אוֹמְרִים ״אָשִׁירָה לַה׳״, מֹשֶׁה אָמַר ״כִּי גָאֹה גָּאָה״, וְהֵן אוֹמְרִים ״כִּי גָאֹה גָּאָה״.
רַבִּי נְחֶמְיָה אוֹמֵר: כְּסוֹפֵר הַפּוֹרֵס עַל שְׁמַע בְּבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת, שֶׁהוּא פּוֹתֵחַ תְּחִילָּה וְהֵן עוֹנִין אַחֲרָיו.
בְּמַאי קָמִיפַּלְגִי — רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא סָבַר: ״לֵאמֹר״, אַמִּילְּתָא קַמַּיְיתָא.

וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בְּנוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי סָבַר: ״לֵאמֹר״ — אַכֹּל מִילְּתָא וּמִילְּתָא, וְרַבִּי נְחֶמְיָה סָבַר: ״וַיֹּאמְרוּ״ — דַּאֲמוּר כּוּלְּהוּ בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי, ״לֵאמֹר״ — דִּפְתַח מֹשֶׁה בְּרֵישָׁא.

תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן, דָּרַשׁ רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי: בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁעָלוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל מִן הַיָּם נָתְנוּ עֵינֵיהֶם לוֹמַר שִׁירָה. וְכֵיצַד אָמְרוּ שִׁירָה — עוֹלָל מוּטָּל עַל בִּרְכֵּי אִמּוֹ, וְתִינוֹק יוֹנֵק מִשְּׁדֵי אִמּוֹ. כֵּיוָן שֶׁרָאוּ אֶת הַשְּׁכִינָה, עוֹלָל הִגְבִּיהַּ צַוָּארוֹ, וְתִינוֹק שָׁמַט דַּד מִפִּיו, וְאָמְרוּ ״זֶה אֵלִי וְאַנְוֵהוּ״, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״מִפִּי עוֹלְלִים וְיֹנְקִים יִסַּדְתָּ עֹז״.
הָיָה רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: מִנַּיִן שֶׁאֲפִילּוּ עוּבָּרִים שֶׁבִּמְעֵי אִמָּן אָמְרוּ שִׁירָה — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר:
״בְּמַקְהֵלוֹת בָּרְכוּ אֱלֹהִים ה׳ מִמְּקוֹר יִשְׂרָאֵל״.
וְהָא לָא חֲזוֹ? אָמַר רַבִּי תַּנְחוּם: כָּרֵס נַעֲשָׂה לָהֶן כְּאַסְפַּקְלַרְיָא הַמְּאִירָה וְרָאוּ.
בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם דָּרַשׁ רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן הוּרְקָנוֹס שֶׁלֹּא עָבַד אִיּוֹב כּוּ׳. וְלִיחְזֵי הַאי ״לֹא״, אִי בְּלָמֶד אָלֶף כְּתִיב — ״לֹא״ הוּא, אִי בְּלָמֶד וָיו כְּתִיב — ״לוֹ״ הוּא?
וְכׇל הֵיכָא דִּכְתִיב בְּלָמֶד אָלֶף, ״לֹא״ הוּא? אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה ״בְּכׇל צָרָתָם לֹא צָר״, דִּכְתִיב בְּלָמֶד אָלֶף, הָכִי נָמֵי דְּ״לֹא״ הוּא?
וְכִי תֵּימָא הָכִי נָמֵי, וְהָכְתִיב ״וּמַלְאַךְ פָּנָיו הוֹשִׁיעָם״! אֶלָּא לָאו, מַשְׁמַע הָכִי וּמַשְׁמַע הָכִי.

תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: נֶאֱמַר ״יְרֵא אֱלֹהִים״ בְּאִיּוֹב, וְנֶאֱמַר ״יְרֵא אֱלֹהִים״ בְּאַבְרָהָם, מָה ״יְרֵא אֱלֹהִים״ הָאָמוּר בְּאַבְרָהָם — מֵאַהֲבָה, אַף ״יְרֵא אֱלֹהִים״ הָאָמוּר בְּאִיּוֹב — מֵאַהֲבָה.
וְאַבְרָהָם גּוּפֵיהּ מְנָלַן — דִּכְתִיב ״זֶרַע אַבְרָהָם אֹהֲבִי״.

מַאי אִיכָּא בֵּין עוֹשֶׂה מֵאַהֲבָה לְעוֹשֶׂה מִיִּרְאָה? אִיכָּא הָא דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: גָּדוֹל הָעוֹשֶׂה מֵאַהֲבָה יוֹתֵר מִן הָעוֹשֶׂה מִיִּרְאָה, שֶׁזֶּה תָּלוּי לְאֶלֶף דּוֹר. וְזֶה תָּלוּי לְאַלְפַּיִם דּוֹר.
הָכָא כְּתִיב: ״לַאֲלָפִים לְאֹהֲבַי וּלְשֹׁמְרֵי מִצְוֹתָי״, וְהָתָם כְּתִיב: ״וּלְשֹׁמְרֵי מִצְוֹתָיו לְאֶלֶף דּוֹר״.
הָתָם נָמֵי כְּתִיב ״לְאֹהֲבָיו וּלְשֹׁמְרֵי מִצְוֹתָיו לְאֶלֶף דּוֹר״!
הַאי לְדִסְמִיךְ לֵיהּ וְהַאי לְדִסְמִיךְ לֵיהּ.

הָנְהוּ תְּרֵי תַּלְמִידֵי דַּהֲווֹ יָתְבִי קַמֵּיהּ דְּרָבָא, חַד אָמַר לֵיהּ אַקְרְיוּן בְּחֶלְמַאי: ״מָה רַב טוּבְךָ אֲשֶׁר צָפַנְתָּ לִּירֵאֶיךָ״, וְחַד אָמַר לֵיהּ: אַקְרְיוּן בְּחֶלְמַאי ״וְיִשְׂמְחוּ כׇל חוֹסֵי בָךְ לְעוֹלָם יְרַנֵּנוּ וְיַעְלְצוּ בְךָ אֹהֲבֵי שְׁמֶךָ״. אֲמַר לְהוּ: תַּרְוַיְיכוּ רַבָּנַן צַדִּיקֵי גְּמוּרֵי אַתּוּן. מָר מֵאַהֲבָה, וּמָר מִיִּרְאָה.
הֲדַרַן עֲלָךְ כְּשֵׁם שֶׁהַמַּיִם
מִי שֶׁקִּינֵּא לְאִשְׁתּוֹ וְנִסְתְּרָה, אֲפִילּוּ שָׁמַע מֵעוֹף הַפּוֹרֵחַ — יוֹצִיא וְיִתֵּן כְּתוּבָּה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.
רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: עַד שֶׁיִּשְׂאוּ וְיִתְּנוּ בָּהּ מוֹזְרוֹת בַּלְּבָנָה.
אָמַר עֵד אֶחָד ״אֲנִי רְאִיתִיהָ שֶׁנִּטְמֵאת״ — לֹא הָיְתָה שׁוֹתָה. וְלֹא עוֹד, אֶלָּא אֲפִילּוּ עֶבֶד אֲפִילּוּ שִׁפְחָה — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ נֶאֱמָנִין אַף לְפוֹסְלָהּ מִכְּתוּבָּתָהּ.
חֲמוֹתָהּ וּבַת חֲמוֹתָהּ וְצָרָתָהּ וִיבִמְתָּהּ וּבַת בַּעְלָהּ — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ נֶאֱמָנוֹת. וְלֹא לְפוֹסְלָהּ מִכְּתוּבָּתָהּ, אֶלָּא שֶׁלֹּא תִּשְׁתֶּה.

שֶׁהָיָה בַּדִּין: וּמָה אִם עֵדוּת רִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינָהּ מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם, עֵדוּת אַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא תִּתְקַיֵּים בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם?
תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְעֵד אֵין בָּהּ״, כׇּל עֵדוּת שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהּ.
וְקַל וָחוֹמֶר לְעֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה מֵעַתָּה: וּמָה אִם

Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana, said: In all the world, one does not perform a third immersion in ordinary water, and here in the case of ordinary water, the tevulim immersed individuals are divided regarding whether it is fit for challah. Mar holds: It is fit like challah whose blood is sprinkled, and Mar holds: It is not like challah whose blood is sprinkled.

And if you wish, say: that all items in the world are susceptible to impurity except for tevel (untithed produce) for it is not like the impurity of blood, and two do not render a third impure with regard to ordinary items, but here (in the case of terumah) it is permitted to cause impurity to ordinary items in the Land of Israel.
Master says: Permitted to cause impurity to common items in the land of Israel, and Master says: Forbidden to cause impurity to common items in the land of Israel.
In it on the day taught Rabbi Akiva and so on.
With what do they disagree? One Master holds: the boundaries of the Torah, and the other Master holds: of the Rabbis.

The Rabbis taught: On that day, Rabbi Akiva expounded: At the moment when the Israelites ascended from the sea, they offered praise, saying a song. And how did they say the song? - "As a mighty one, I will sing to the Lord, and they respond after him, the heads of the chapters." Moses said, "I will sing to the Lord," and they say, "I will sing to the Lord." Moses said, "For exalted, exalted," and they say, "I will sing to the Lord."

Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, says: Like a minor who reads the Hallel, and they respond after him with everything he says. Moses said, "I will sing to the Lord," and they say, "I will sing to the Lord." Moses said, "For exalted, exalted," and they say, "For exalted, exalted."
Rabbi Nechemiah says: Like a scribe who reads aloud in the synagogue, who begins first and they respond after him.
In what do they disagree? — Rabbi Akiva holds: "to say," is the primary point.

Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, holds: "to say" — eat each and every word, and Rabbi Nechemiah holds: "and they said" — that they all said together, "to say" — for Moses began at the outset.

The Rabbis taught: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean expounded: When the Israelites ascended from the sea, they directed their eyes to say a song. And how did they say the song? — A suckling babe on his mother's knees, and a nursing child from his mother's breasts. As soon as they saw the Divine Presence, the babe raised his neck, and the child released the breast from his mouth, and they said, "This is my God, and I will glorify Him," as it is stated: "Out of the mouth of babes and sucklings You have established strength."

And all places where it is written with a "lamed aleph," "lo" is it not? Rather from now on "b'kol tzaratam lo tzar," as it is written with a "lamed aleph," so too is it that "lo" is it not?
And if you will say so, it is stated "and an angel of His presence saved them"! Rather, no, understand it this way and understand it this way.

It was taught: Rabbi Meir says: It is stated "he fears God" regarding Job, and it is stated "he fears God" regarding Abraham. Just as the "fears God" said about Abraham is from love, so too the "fears God" said about Job is from love.
And Abraham, his body, where are they from - as it is written, "The seed of Abraham, My lover."

Talmudic text: What is the difference between one who acts out of love and one who acts out of fear? There is the one that it teaches, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Greater is the one who acts out of love more than the one who acts out of fear, for this one is dependent on a thousand generations. And this one is dependent on two thousand generations.

Here is the English translation of the Talmudic text: Talmudic text: Here it is written: "To thousands of those who love Me and keep My commandments," and there it is written: "And to those who keep His commandments to a thousand generations."
There, it is written: "to those who love Him and keep His commandments to a thousand generations"!
This one for support to him, and this one for support to him.

And the other said to him, "Read in your dreams: 'And let all who take refuge in You rejoice; let them ever shout for joy, and may You shelter them; let those who love Your name exult in You.'" He said to them: "You are truly righteous scholars. One loves out of love, and one out of fear."

Rabbi Yehoshua says: Until they lift and place in it (the basket) the straps in the moon.
He said, one witness "I saw her becoming impure" — she did not drink. And not only that, but even a slave or even a maidservant — these are believed even to disqualify her from her marriage contract.

Her mother-in-law, her daughter-in-law, her rival, her co-wife, and her husband's daughter from another wife - these are considered trustworthy. And not to disqualify her from her marriage contract, but that she should not drink.

sentences.llm_translation: Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana, said: In all the world, one does not perform a third immersion in ordinary water, and here in the case of ordinary water, the tevulim immersed individuals are divided regarding whether it is fit for challah. Mar holds: It is fit like challah whose blood is sprinkled, and Mar holds: It is not like challah whose blood is sprinkled.

sentences.text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא חוּלִּין הַטְּבוּלִין לְחַלָּה לָא כְּחַלָּה דָּמוּ, וְאֵין שֵׁנִי עוֹשֶׂה שְׁלִישִׁי בְּחוּלִּין, וְהָכָא בְּמוּתָּר לִגְרוֹם טוּמְאָה לְחוּלִּין שֶׁבְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל קָמִיפַּלְגִי.
sentences.human_translation: And if you wish, say Everyone non-sacred untithed with regard to ḥalla is not like ḥalla and cannot impart to non-sacred items. But here, they disagree with regard to it is permitted to cause ritual impurity to non-sacred that is in Eretz Yisrael.
sentences.llm_translation: And if you wish, say: that all items in the world are susceptible to impurity except for tevel (untithed produce) for it is not like the impurity of blood, and two do not render a third impure with regard to ordinary items, but here (in the case of terumah) it is permitted to cause impurity to ordinary items in the Land of Israel.

sentences.text: מָר סָבַר: מוּתָּר לִגְרוֹם טוּמְאָה לְחוּלִּין שֶׁבְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל, וּמָר סָבַר: אָסוּר לִגְרוֹם טוּמְאָה לְחוּלִּין שֶׁבְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל.
sentences.human_translation: Sage, holds it is permitted to cause impurity to non-sacred that is in Eretz Yisrael. And Sage, holds it is prohibited to cause impurity to non-sacred that is in Eretz Yisrael.
sentences.llm_translation: Master says: Permitted to cause impurity to common items in the land of Israel, and Master says: Forbidden to cause impurity to common items in the land of Israel.

sentences.text: בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם דָּרַשׁ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וְכוּ׳.
sentences.human_translation: On that same day Rabbi Akiva interpreted
sentences.llm_translation: In it on the day taught Rabbi Akiva and so on.

sentences.text: בְּמַאי קָא מִיפַּלְגִי? מָר סָבַר: תְּחוּמִין דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, וּמָר סָבַר: דְּרַבָּנַן.
sentences.human_translation: With regard to what do they disagree? Sage, holds boundaries by Torah law, and Sage, holds by rabbinic law,
sentences.llm_translation: With what do they disagree? One Master holds: the boundaries of the Torah, and the other Master holds: of the Rabbis.

sentences.text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן, בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם דָּרַשׁ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁעָלוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל מִן הַיָּם, נָתְנוּ עֵינֵיהֶם לוֹמַר שִׁירָה. וְכֵיצַד אָמְרוּ שִׁירָה — כְּגָדוֹל הַמַּקְרֶא אֶת הַלֵּל, וְהֵן עוֹנִין אַחֲרָיו רָאשֵׁי פְרָקִים. מֹשֶׁה אָמַר ״אָשִׁירָה לַה׳״, וְהֵן אוֹמְרִים ״אָשִׁירָה לַה׳״, מֹשֶׁה אָמַר ״כִּי גָאֹה גָּאָה״ וְהֵן אוֹמְרִים ״אָשִׁירָה לַה׳״.
sentences.human_translation: The Sages taught: On that same day Rabbi Akiva taught at the time that the Jewish people ascended from the sea they set their eyes on reciting a song And how did they recite song? as an adult man reciting hallel and recite after him the chapter headings Moses said: “I will sing unto the Lord” and said “I will sing unto the Lord.” Moses said: “For He is highly exalted” and they said “I will sing unto the Lord.”
sentences.llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: On that day, Rabbi Akiva expounded: At the moment when the Israelites ascended from the sea, they offered praise, saying a song. And how did they say the song? - "As a mighty one, I will sing to the Lord, and they respond after him, the heads of the chapters." Moses said, "I will sing to the Lord," and they say, "I will sing to the Lord." Moses said, "For exalted, exalted," and they say, "I will sing to the Lord."

sentences.text: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בְּנוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי אוֹמֵר: כְּקָטָן הַמַּקְרֶא אֶת הַלֵּל, וְהֵן עוֹנִין אַחֲרָיו כׇּל מָה שֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר. מֹשֶׁה אָמַר ״אָשִׁירָה לַה׳״ וְהֵן אוֹמְרִים ״אָשִׁירָה לַה׳״, מֹשֶׁה אָמַר ״כִּי גָאֹה גָּאָה״, וְהֵן אוֹמְרִים ״כִּי גָאֹה גָּאָה״.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, says: like a minor boy reciting hallel and repeat after him all that he says, Moses said: “I will sing unto the Lord” and said “I will sing to the Lord.” Moses said: “For He is highly exalted,” and they said “For He is highly exalted.”
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, says: Like a minor who reads the Hallel, and they respond after him with everything he says. Moses said, "I will sing to the Lord," and they say, "I will sing to the Lord." Moses said, "For exalted, exalted," and they say, "For exalted, exalted."

sentences.text: רַבִּי נְחֶמְיָה אוֹמֵר: כְּסוֹפֵר הַפּוֹרֵס עַל שְׁמַע בְּבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת, שֶׁהוּא פּוֹתֵחַ תְּחִילָּה וְהֵן עוֹנִין אַחֲרָיו.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Neḥemya says: like a scribe, who recites the Shema in the synagogue; as he begins first and they repeat after him
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Nechemiah says: Like a scribe who reads aloud in the synagogue, who begins first and they respond after him.

sentences.text: בְּמַאי קָמִיפַּלְגִי — רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא סָבַר: ״לֵאמֹר״, אַמִּילְּתָא קַמַּיְיתָא.
sentences.human_translation: With regard to what do they disagree? Rabbi Akiva holds “saying,” to the first words
sentences.llm_translation: In what do they disagree? — Rabbi Akiva holds: "to say," is the primary point.

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בְּנוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי סָבַר: ״לֵאמֹר״ — אַכֹּל מִילְּתָא וּמִילְּתָא, וְרַבִּי נְחֶמְיָה סָבַר: ״וַיֹּאמְרוּ״ — דַּאֲמוּר כּוּלְּהוּ בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי, ״לֵאמֹר״ — דִּפְתַח מֹשֶׁה בְּרֵישָׁא.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, holds “saying” to every single word, And Rabbi Neḥemya holds “and they said” that everyone recited together, “saying” that Moses began first;
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, holds: "to say" — eat each and every word, and Rabbi Nechemiah holds: "and they said" — that they all said together, "to say" — for Moses began at the outset.

sentences.text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן, דָּרַשׁ רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי: בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁעָלוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל מִן הַיָּם נָתְנוּ עֵינֵיהֶם לוֹמַר שִׁירָה. וְכֵיצַד אָמְרוּ שִׁירָה — עוֹלָל מוּטָּל עַל בִּרְכֵּי אִמּוֹ, וְתִינוֹק יוֹנֵק מִשְּׁדֵי אִמּוֹ. כֵּיוָן שֶׁרָאוּ אֶת הַשְּׁכִינָה, עוֹלָל הִגְבִּיהַּ צַוָּארוֹ, וְתִינוֹק שָׁמַט דַּד מִפִּיו, וְאָמְרוּ ״זֶה אֵלִי וְאַנְוֵהוּ״, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״מִפִּי עוֹלְלִים וְיֹנְקִים יִסַּדְתָּ עֹז״.
sentences.human_translation: The Sages taught Rabbi Yosei HaGelili taught: At the time that the Jewish people ascended from the sea they resolved to sing And how did they recite a baby lying on his mother’s lap or an infant nursing from his mother’s breasts, once they saw the Divine Presence, the baby straightened his neck and the infant dropped the breast from his mouth, and they recited: “This is my God and I will glorify Him” As it is stated: “Out of the mouths of babies and sucklings You have founded strength”
sentences.llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean expounded: When the Israelites ascended from the sea, they directed their eyes to say a song. And how did they say the song? — A suckling babe on his mother's knees, and a nursing child from his mother's breasts. As soon as they saw the Divine Presence, the babe raised his neck, and the child released the breast from his mouth, and they said, "This is my God, and I will glorify Him," as it is stated: "Out of the mouth of babes and sucklings You have established strength."

sentences.text: הָיָה רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: מִנַּיִן שֶׁאֲפִילּוּ עוּבָּרִים שֶׁבִּמְעֵי אִמָּן אָמְרוּ שִׁירָה — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר:
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Meir would say: From where that even fetuses in their mother’s womb recited song As it is stated:
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rabbi Meir used to say: From where do we derive that even fetuses in their mother's womb recited a song? As it is stated: (

sentences.text: ״בְּמַקְהֵלוֹת בָּרְכוּ אֱלֹהִים ה׳ מִמְּקוֹר יִשְׂרָאֵל״.
sentences.human_translation: “In full assemblies, bless God, the Lord, you that are from the source of Israel”
sentences.llm_translation: "In the assemblies bless God, the Lord, from the source of Israel."

sentences.text: וְהָא לָא חֲזוֹ? אָמַר רַבִּי תַּנְחוּם: כָּרֵס נַעֲשָׂה לָהֶן כְּאַסְפַּקְלַרְיָא הַמְּאִירָה וְרָאוּ.
sentences.human_translation: But could not see, Rabbi Tanḥum says: stomach was transformed for them like luminous crystal [ aspaklarya ], and they saw
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And did he not see? Rabbi Tanhum said: A palace was made for them like a sapphire that shines, and they saw."

sentences.text: בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם דָּרַשׁ רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן הוּרְקָנוֹס שֶׁלֹּא עָבַד אִיּוֹב כּוּ׳. וְלִיחְזֵי הַאי ״לֹא״, אִי בְּלָמֶד אָלֶף כְּתִיב — ״לֹא״ הוּא, אִי בְּלָמֶד וָיו כְּתִיב — ״לוֹ״ הוּא?
sentences.human_translation: On that same day Rabbi Yehoshua ben Hyrcanus taught that Job served only Let us see whether this lo is written lamed alef , is: not whether it is written lamed vav , is: in Him.
sentences.llm_translation: In it on the day, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Hurkanos expounded that Job did not sin. And regarding this "לֹא," if written with an Aleph, it is "לֹא," if written with a Vav, it is "לוֹ"?

sentences.text: וְכׇל הֵיכָא דִּכְתִיב בְּלָמֶד אָלֶף, ״לֹא״ הוּא? אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה ״בְּכׇל צָרָתָם לֹא צָר״, דִּכְתִיב בְּלָמֶד אָלֶף, הָכִי נָמֵי דְּ״לֹא״ הוּא?
sentences.human_translation: But anywhere that is written lamed alef , is: Not? If that is so, “In all their affliction He was [ lo ] afflicted” where is written lamed alef , so too, does it Not,
sentences.llm_translation: And all places where it is written with a "lamed aleph," "lo" is it not? Rather from now on "b'kol tzaratam lo tzar," as it is written with a "lamed aleph," so too is it that "lo" is it not?

sentences.text: וְכִי תֵּימָא הָכִי נָמֵי, וְהָכְתִיב ״וּמַלְאַךְ פָּנָיו הוֹשִׁיעָם״! אֶלָּא לָאו, מַשְׁמַע הָכִי וּמַשְׁמַע הָכִי.
sentences.human_translation: And if you would say indeed but isn’t it written “And the angel of His Presence saved them,” Rather, is it not indicates this and indicates that?
sentences.llm_translation: And if you will say so, it is stated "and an angel of His presence saved them"! Rather, no, understand it this way and understand it this way.

sentences.text: תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: נֶאֱמַר ״יְרֵא אֱלֹהִים״ בְּאִיּוֹב, וְנֶאֱמַר ״יְרֵא אֱלֹהִים״ בְּאַבְרָהָם, מָה ״יְרֵא אֱלֹהִים״ הָאָמוּר בְּאַבְרָהָם — מֵאַהֲבָה, אַף ״יְרֵא אֱלֹהִים״ הָאָמוּר בְּאִיּוֹב — מֵאַהֲבָה.
sentences.human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Meir says: It is stated with regard to Job “God-fearing” and it is stated with regard to Abraham “God-fearing” Just as “God-fearing,” which is stated with regard to Abraham, out of love, so too, “God-fearing” that is stated with regard to Job out of love.
sentences.llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Meir says: It is stated "he fears God" regarding Job, and it is stated "he fears God" regarding Abraham. Just as the "fears God" said about Abraham is from love, so too the "fears God" said about Job is from love.

sentences.text: וְאַבְרָהָם גּוּפֵיהּ מְנָלַן — דִּכְתִיב ״זֶרַע אַבְרָהָם אֹהֲבִי״.
sentences.human_translation: And Abraham himself, from where do we As it is written: “The offspring of Abraham who loved Me”
sentences.llm_translation: And Abraham, his body, where are they from - as it is written, "The seed of Abraham, My lover."

sentences.text: מַאי אִיכָּא בֵּין עוֹשֶׂה מֵאַהֲבָה לְעוֹשֶׂה מִיִּרְאָה? אִיכָּא הָא דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: גָּדוֹל הָעוֹשֶׂה מֵאַהֲבָה יוֹתֵר מִן הָעוֹשֶׂה מִיִּרְאָה, שֶׁזֶּה תָּלוּי לְאֶלֶף דּוֹר. וְזֶה תָּלוּי לְאַלְפַּיִם דּוֹר.
sentences.human_translation: What is there between one who performs out of love and one who performs out of fear? There is that which is taught Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Greater is the one who performs out of love than the one who performs out of fear, as this endure for one thousand generations, and that endure for two thousand generations.
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: What is the difference between one who acts out of love and one who acts out of fear? There is the one that it teaches, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Greater is the one who acts out of love more than the one who acts out of fear, for this one is dependent on a thousand generations. And this one is dependent on two thousand generations.

sentences.text: הָכָא כְּתִיב: ״לַאֲלָפִים לְאֹהֲבַי וּלְשֹׁמְרֵי מִצְוֹתָי״, וְהָתָם כְּתִיב: ״וּלְשֹׁמְרֵי מִצְוֹתָיו לְאֶלֶף דּוֹר״.
sentences.human_translation: here it is written: “And showing mercy unto thousands of generations of those who love Me and keep My commandments” and there it is written: and keep His commandments for a thousand generations”
sentences.llm_translation: Here is the English translation of the Talmudic text: Talmudic text: Here it is written: "To thousands of those who love Me and keep My commandments," and there it is written: "And to those who keep His commandments to a thousand generations."

sentences.text: הָתָם נָמֵי כְּתִיב ״לְאֹהֲבָיו וּלְשֹׁמְרֵי מִצְוֹתָיו לְאֶלֶף דּוֹר״!
sentences.human_translation: there also, it is written: with those who love Him and keep His commandments for a thousand generations”
sentences.llm_translation: There, it is written: "to those who love Him and keep His commandments to a thousand generations"!

sentences.text: הַאי לְדִסְמִיךְ לֵיהּ וְהַאי לְדִסְמִיךְ לֵיהּ.
sentences.human_translation: That to that which is adjacent to it. And this to that which is adjacent to it:
sentences.llm_translation: This one for support to him, and this one for support to him.

sentences.text: הָנְהוּ תְּרֵי תַּלְמִידֵי דַּהֲווֹ יָתְבִי קַמֵּיהּ דְּרָבָא, חַד אָמַר לֵיהּ אַקְרְיוּן בְּחֶלְמַאי: ״מָה רַב טוּבְךָ אֲשֶׁר צָפַנְתָּ לִּירֵאֶיךָ״, וְחַד אָמַר לֵיהּ: אַקְרְיוּן בְּחֶלְמַאי ״וְיִשְׂמְחוּ כׇל חוֹסֵי בָךְ לְעוֹלָם יְרַנֵּנוּ וְיַעְלְצוּ בְךָ אֹהֲבֵי שְׁמֶךָ״. אֲמַר לְהוּ: תַּרְוַיְיכוּ רַבָּנַן צַדִּיקֵי גְּמוּרֵי אַתּוּן. מָר מֵאַהֲבָה, וּמָר מִיִּרְאָה.
sentences.human_translation: these two students who were sitting before Rava, one said to him: It was read to me in my dream: “How abundant is Your goodness, which You have laid up for those who fear You” And one said to It was read to me in my dream: “So shall all those who take refuge in You rejoice; they will forever shout for joy, let them also who love Your name exult in You” said to them: You are both completely righteous Sages. Sage, out of love, and Sage, out of fear.
sentences.llm_translation: Behold, there were two disciples who were sitting before Rava. One said to him, "Read in your dreams: 'How great is Your goodness that You have hidden for those who fear You.'" And the other said to him, "Read in your dreams: 'And let all who take refuge in You rejoice; let them ever shout for joy, and may You shelter them; let those who love Your name exult in You.'" He said to them: "You are truly righteous scholars. One loves out of love, and one out of fear."

sentences.llm_translation: One who is jealous of his wife and she concealed herself, even if he heard from a bird in flight - he must divorce her and give her the marriage contract, the words of Rabbi Eliezer.

sentences.text: אָמַר עֵד אֶחָד ״אֲנִי רְאִיתִיהָ שֶׁנִּטְמֵאת״ — לֹא הָיְתָה שׁוֹתָה. וְלֹא עוֹד, אֶלָּא אֲפִילּוּ עֶבֶד אֲפִילּוּ שִׁפְחָה — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ נֶאֱמָנִין אַף לְפוֹסְלָהּ מִכְּתוּבָּתָהּ.

sentences.llm_translation: He said, one witness "I saw her becoming impure" — she did not drink. And not only that, but even a slave or even a maidservant — these are believed even to disqualify her from her marriage contract.

sentences.text: חֲמוֹתָהּ וּבַת חֲמוֹתָהּ וְצָרָתָהּ וִיבִמְתָּהּ וּבַת בַּעְלָהּ — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ נֶאֱמָנוֹת. וְלֹא לְפוֹסְלָהּ מִכְּתוּבָּתָהּ, אֶלָּא שֶׁלֹּא תִּשְׁתֶּה.

sentences.llm_translation: Her mother-in-law, her daughter-in-law, her rival, her co-wife, and her husband's daughter from another wife - these are considered trustworthy. And not to disqualify her from her marriage contract, but that she should not drink.

sentences.text: שֶׁהָיָה בַּדִּין: וּמָה אִם עֵדוּת רִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינָהּ מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם, עֵדוּת אַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא תִּתְקַיֵּים בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם?

sentences.llm_translation: In the case of a judgment: And what if the first testimony, which does not render her permanently forbidden - is not upheld by less than two witnesses, the last testimony, which renders her permanently forbidden - is it not a judgment that is not upheld by less than two witnesses?

text: שֶׁמְּבַזְבְּזִין דִּין אֲבִיהֶם לֶעָתִיד לָבוֹא. אוֹמְרִים לְפָנָיו: רִבּוֹנוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם, מֵאַחַר שֶׁאַתָּה עָתִיד לִיפָּרַע מֵהֶן, לָמָה הִקְהֵיתָה שִׁינֵּיהֶם בָּם?

אָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא בַּר יְבֶרֶכְיָה: אִלְמָלֵא תְּפִלָּתוֹ שֶׁל דָּוִד, הָיוּ כׇּל יִשְׂרָאֵל מוֹכְרֵי רְבָב, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שִׁיתָה ה׳ מוֹרָה לָהֶם״. וְאָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא בַּר יְבֶרֶכְיָה: אִלְמָלֵא תְּפִלָּתוֹ שֶׁל חֲבַקּוּק, הָיוּ שְׁנֵי תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים מִתְכַּסִּים בְּטַלִּית אַחַת וְעוֹסְקִין בַּתּוֹרָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״ה׳ שָׁמַעְתִּי שִׁמְעֲךָ יָרֵאתִי ה׳ פׇּעׇלְךָ בְּקֶרֶב שָׁנִים חַיֵּיהוּ״. אַל תִּקְרָא ״בְּקֶרֶב שָׁנִים״, אֶלָּא ״בְּקֵרוּב שְׁנַיִם״.

וְאָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא בַּר יְבֶרֶכְיָה: שְׁנֵי תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים הַמְהַלְּכִין בַּדֶּרֶךְ וְאֵין בֵּינֵיהֶן דִּבְרֵי תוֹרָה — רְאוּיִן לִישָּׂרֵף בָּאֵשׁ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיְהִי הֵמָּה הֹלְכִים הָלוֹךְ וְדַבֵּר וְהִנֵּה רֶכֶב אֵשׁ וְגוֹ׳״, טַעְמָא דְּאִיכָּא דִּיבּוּר, הָא לֵיכָּא דִּיבּוּר — רְאוּיִן לִישָּׂרֵף.

וְאָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא בַּר יְבֶרֶכְיָה: שְׁנֵי תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים הַדָּרִין בְּעִיר אַחַת וְאֵין נוֹחִין זֶה לָזֶה בַּהֲלָכָה — אֶחָד מֵת וְאֶחָד גּוֹלֶה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לָנֻס שָׁמָּה רוֹצֵחַ אֲשֶׁר יִרְצַח אֶת רֵעֵהוּ בִּבְלִי דַעַת״, וְאֵין דַּעַת אֶלָּא תּוֹרָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״נִדְמוּ עַמִּי מִבְּלִי הַדָּעַת״.

אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי חִיָּיא: כׇּל תַּלְמִיד חָכָם הָעוֹסֵק בַּתּוֹרָה מִתּוֹךְ הַדְּחָק — תְּפִלָּתוֹ נִשְׁמַעַת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי עַם בְּצִיּוֹן יֵשֵׁב בִּירוּשָׁלִָם בָּכוֹ לֹא תִבְכֶּה חָנוֹן יׇחְנְךָ לְקוֹל זַעֲקֶךָ כְּשׇׁמְעָתוֹ עָנָךְ״, וּכְתִיב בָּתְרֵיהּ: ״וְנָתַן ה׳ לָכֶם לֶחֶם צָר וּמַיִם לָחַץ״.

רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אוֹמֵר: מַשְׁבִּיעִין אוֹתוֹ מִזִּיו שְׁכִינָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָיוּ עֵינֶיךָ רֹאוֹת אֶת מוֹרֶיךָ״. רַבִּי אַחָא בַּר חֲנִינָא אָמַר: אַף אֵין הַפַּרְגּוֹד נִנְעָל בְּפָנָיו, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא יִכָּנֵף עוֹד מוֹרֶיךָ״.

רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: מִיּוֹם שֶׁחָרַב בֵּית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ אֵין וְכוּ׳. אָמַר רָבָא: בְּכׇל יוֹם וָיוֹם מְרוּבָּה קִלְלָתוֹ מִשֶּׁל חֲבֵירוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בַּבֹּקֶר תֹּאמַר מִי יִתֵּן עֶרֶב וּבָעֶרֶב תֹּאמַר מִי יִתֵּן בֹּקֶר״, הֵי בֹּקֶר? אִילֵימָא בֹּקֶר דְּלִמְחַר, מִי יָדַע מַאי הָוֵי? אֶלָּא דַּחֲלֵיף.

וְאֶלָּא, עָלְמָא אַמַּאי קָא מִקַּיַּים? אַקְּדוּשָּׁה דְסִידְרָא, וְאַ״יְּהֵא שְׁמֵיהּ רַבָּא״ דְּאַגַּדְתָּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אֶרֶץ עֵיפָתָה כְּמוֹ אֹפֶל צַלְמָוֶת וְלֹא סְדָרִים״, הָא יֵשׁ סְדָרִים — תּוֹפִיעַ מֵאוֹפֶל.
וְלֹא יָרַד טַל לִבְרָכָה וְנִיטַּל טַעַם פֵּירוֹת וְכוּ׳. תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: טׇהֳרָה — בִּטְּלָה טַעַם וָרֵיחַ, מַעֲשֵׂר — בִּיטֵּל שׁוֹמֶן דָּגָן.

רַב הוּנָא אַשְׁכַּח תּוֹמַרְתָּא דְּחִינוּנִיתָא, שַׁקְלַהּ, כַּרְכַהּ בְּסוּדָרֵיהּ. אֲתָא רַבָּה בְּרֵיהּ, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מוֹרְחִינָא רֵיחָא דְּחִינוּנִיתָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: בְּנִי, טׇהֳרָה יֵשׁ בְּךָ. יַהֲבַהּ נִיהֲלֵיהּ. אַדְּהָכִי אֲתָא אַבָּא בְּרֵיהּ, שַׁקְלַהּ, יַהֲבַהּ נִיהֲלֵיהּ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: בְּנִי, שִׂמַּחְתָּ אֶת לִבִּי, וְהִקְהֵיתָה אֶת שִׁינַּי. הַיְינוּ דְּאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי: רַחֲמֵי דְּאַבָּא — אַבְּנֵי, רַחֲמֵי דִּבְנֵי — אַבְּנֵי דְּהָווּ לֵיהּ.

רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב אִיטַּפַּל בֵּיהּ בְּרַב יַעֲקֹב בַּר בְּרַתֵּיה. כִּי גְדַל אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אַשְׁקְיַין מַיָּא. אָמַר לוֹ: לָאו בְּרָיךְ אֲנָא. וְהַיְינוּ דְּאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי: רַבִּי רַבִּי, בַּר בְּרַתָּךְ אֲנָא.
מַתְנִי׳ בְּפוּלְמוּס שֶׁל אַסְפַּסְיָינוּס גָּזְרוּ עַל עַטְרוֹת חֲתָנִים וְעַל הָאִירוּס.
בְּפוּלְמוּס שֶׁל טִיטוּס גָּזְרוּ עַל עַטְרוֹת כַּלּוֹת, וְשֶׁלֹּא יְלַמֵּד אָדָם אֶת בְּנוֹ יְווֹנִית.
בְּפוּלְמוּס הָאַחֲרוֹן גָּזְרוּ שֶׁלֹּא תֵּצֵא הַכַּלָּה בְּאַפִּרְיוֹן בְּתוֹךְ הָעִיר, וְרַבּוֹתֵינוּ הִתִּירוּ שֶׁתֵּצֵא הַכַּלָּה בְּאַפִּרְיוֹן בְּתוֹךְ הָעִיר.

מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי מֵאִיר בָּטְלוּ מוֹשְׁלֵי מְשָׁלִים. מִשֶּׁמֵּת בֶּן עַזַּאי בָּטְלוּ הַשַּׁקְדָנִים. מִשֶּׁמֵּת בֶּן זוֹמָא בָּטְלוּ הַדַּרְשָׁנִים. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא בָּטַל כְּבוֹד הַתּוֹרָה. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי חֲנִינָא בֶּן דּוֹסָא בָּטְלוּ אַנְשֵׁי מַעֲשֶׂה. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי יוֹסֵי קְטֹנְתָּא פָּסְקוּ חֲסִידִים. וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמוֹ ״קְטֹנְתָּא״ — שֶׁהָיָה קְטֹנְתָּא שֶׁל חֲסִידִים.

מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבָּן יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי בָּטַל זִיו הַחׇכְמָה. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל הַזָּקֵן בָּטַל כְּבוֹד הַתּוֹרָה, וּמֵתָה טׇהֳרָה וּפְרִישׁוּת. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בֶּן פִּאָבִי בָּטְלָה זִיו הַכְּהוּנָּה. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי בָּטְלָ[ה] עֲנָוָה וְיִרְאַת חֵטְא.

רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הַגָּדוֹל אוֹמֵר: מִיּוֹם שֶׁחָרַב בֵּית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ שָׁרוֹ חַכִּימַיָּא לְמֶהֱוֵי כְּסָפְרַיָּא, וְסָפְרַיָּא כְּחַזָּנַיָּא, וְחַזָּנַיָּא כְּעַמָּא דְאַרְעָא, וְעַמָּא דְאַרְעָא
llm_translation: They degrade the judgment of their Father in Heaven. They say before Him: Master of the Universe, since You are destined to avenge Yourself from them, why did You provoke them with Your teeth?

Said Rabbi Ilai son of Yivraḥya: Were it not for the prayer of David, all of Israel would have been sold for a quarter, as it is stated: "Set God as a teacher for them." And Rabbi Ilai son of Yivraḥya said: Were it not for the prayer of Ḥavakuk, two Torah scholars would cover themselves with one cloak and engage in Torah study, as it is stated: "O Lord, I have heard the report about You, I am awed, O Lord, by Your deeds; renew them in these years, make them known in these years." Do not read it as "in these years," but rather as "in the closeness of two."

And Rabbi Ilai son of Yevarekhiya said: Two Torah scholars walking on the road, and there are no words of Torah between them — they are deserving to be burned with fire, as it is stated: "And it came to pass, as they still went on, and talked, that, behold, there appeared a chariot of fire," (2 Kings 2:11). The reason for speech is present, but if there is no speech — they are deserving to be burned.

And said Rabbi Ilai son of Yevarekhiya: Two students of sages who reside in one city and do not find rest with one another in matters of halakha — one dies and one goes into exile, as it is said: "To a city of refuge shall the manslayer flee, he who kills his fellow unintentionally," and there is no knowledge except Torah, as it is said: "My people are destroyed for lack of knowledge."

Said Rabbi Yehudah, son of Rabbi Chiya: Every Torah scholar who studies Torah under duress - his prayer is heard, as it is stated: "For a people shall dwell in Zion, in Jerusalem; you shall not weep. He will surely be gracious to you at the sound of your cry; when He hears, He will answer you." And it is written further: "And the Lord will give you bread in adversity and water in oppression."

Rabbi Abbahu says: We swear him from the radiance of the Divine Presence, as it is said: "And your eyes shall see your teachers." Rabbi Acha bar Chanina says: Even the Paragog is not locked in front of him, as it is said: "And your teachers shall not be hidden anymore."

Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua: "From the day the Temple was destroyed, there is no..." Rava said: "Every day his curse is greater than his fellow's, as it is stated: 'In the morning you will say, 'If only it were evening!' and in the evening you will say, 'If only it were morning!'' Is it morning? Perhaps it is evening, who knows what will be? Rather, it is alternating."

Talmudic text: And rather, why is the world established? The holiness of order, and "And His name shall be called Wonderful Counselor" as you have expounded, as it is stated: "The land of deep darkness, like the shadow of death, and there is order" — it emerges from darkness.

The text reads as follows: "And dew did not descend for blessing, and the taste of fruits was removed, etc." It was taught: Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Purity - it nullified the taste and smell, tithes - it nullified the oil of the grain.

Rav Huna found a date-palm of the Chinnunith variety, he uprooted it, replanted it in its place. Rabbah, his son, came, said to him: I smell the fragrance of the Chinnunith. He said to him: My son, you have purity. He gave it to him as a gift. Meanwhile, Abba, his father, came, uprooted it, gave it to him as a gift. He said to him: My son, you have gladdened my heart, and you have sweetened my teeth. This is what people say: The mercies of a father—stones, the mercies of a son—stones that were given to him.

Rav Ahah bar Ya'akov interceded on behalf of Rav Ya'akov bar Bratei. When he grew up, he said to him: "Give me water." He said to him: "I am not a well." And this is what people say: "My master, my master, I am your son-in-law."
The Mishnah: In the city of Pumbedita of Aspasyanus they decreed regarding the crowns of grooms and regarding betrothal.
In the Pulumus of Titus they decreed on bridal crowns, and so that a person should not teach his son Greek.
In Pulumus the latter, they decreed that the bride should not go out in a palanquin within the city, and our Rabbis permitted the bride to go out in a palanquin within the city.

From the death of Rabbi Meir, the interpreters of parables ceased. From the death of Ben Azzai, the almond trees ceased. From the death of Ben Zoma, the expounders ceased. From the death of Rabbi Akiva, the honor of the Torah ceased. From the death of Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa, the men of deeds ceased. From the death of Rabbi Yosei K'tanta, the pious ceased. And why was he called "K'tanta"? Because he was the smallest among the pious.

From when Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai died, the splendor of wisdom ceased. From when Rabban Gamliel the Elder died, the honor of the Torah ceased, and purity and separation ceased. From when Rabbi Yishmael ben Piavi died, the radiance of the priesthood ceased. From when Rabbi died, humility and fear of sin ceased.

G'ma The Rabbis taught: Rabbi Pinchas ben Yair says: When the Temple was destroyed, the members of the community were ashamed, the free men were humiliated, the workers were shaken, the leaders of the arm and the leaders of the tongue prevailed, and no one inquired, and no one sought, and no one asked.
On whom shall we rely? On our Father in Heaven.

sentences.human_translation: Rav Huna found a fragrant date. He took it and wrapped it in his shawl. Rabba, his son, came said to him: I smell the aroma of a fragrant said to him: My son, there is purity in you, He gave it to him. Meanwhile, Abba, son, arrived. took gave it to said to My son, you have made my heart rejoice and you have blunted my teeth, This that people say: The love of a father is for the sons; the love of the sons is for their own sons,
sentences.llm_translation: Rav Huna found a date-palm of the Chinnunith variety, he uprooted it, replanted it in its place. Rabbah, his son, came, said to him: I smell the fragrance of the Chinnunith. He said to him: My son, you have purity. He gave it to him as a gift. Meanwhile, Abba, his father, came, uprooted it, gave it to him as a gift. He said to him: My son, you have gladdened my heart, and you have sweetened my teeth. This is what people say: The mercies of a father—stones, the mercies of a son—stones that were given to him.

sentences.text: רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב אִיטַּפַּל בֵּיהּ בְּרַב יַעֲקֹב בַּר בְּרַתֵּיה. כִּי גְדַל אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אַשְׁקְיַין מַיָּא. אָמַר לוֹ: לָאו בְּרָיךְ אֲנָא. וְהַיְינוּ דְּאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי: רַבִּי רַבִּי, בַּר בְּרַתָּךְ אֲנָא.
sentences.human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov took care of Rav Ya’akov, the son of his daughter, When grew up, said to him: Give me water to drink. He said to him: I am not your son, And this that people say: Raise, raise I am the son of your daughter,
sentences.llm_translation: Rav Ahah bar Ya'akov interceded on behalf of Rav Ya'akov bar Bratei. When he grew up, he said to him: "Give me water." He said to him: "I am not a well." And this is what people say: "My master, my master, I am your son-in-law."

sentences.text: מַתְנִי׳ בְּפוּלְמוּס שֶׁל אַסְפַּסְיָינוּס גָּזְרוּ עַל עַטְרוֹת חֲתָנִים וְעַל הָאִירוּס.
sentences.human_translation: In the war [ pulemus ] of Vespasian decreed upon the crowns of bridegrooms, and upon the drums,
sentences.llm_translation: The Mishnah: In the city of Pumbedita of Aspasyanus they decreed regarding the crowns of grooms and regarding betrothal.

sentences.text: בְּפוּלְמוּס שֶׁל טִיטוּס גָּזְרוּ עַל עַטְרוֹת כַּלּוֹת, וְשֶׁלֹּא יְלַמֵּד אָדָם אֶת בְּנוֹ יְווֹנִית.
sentences.human_translation: In the war of Titus they decreed upon the crowns of brides, and that a person should not teach his son Greek.
sentences.llm_translation: In the Pulumus of Titus they decreed on bridal crowns, and so that a person should not teach his son Greek.

sentences.text: בְּפוּלְמוּס הָאַחֲרוֹן גָּזְרוּ שֶׁלֹּא תֵּצֵא הַכַּלָּה בְּאַפִּרְיוֹן בְּתוֹךְ הָעִיר, וְרַבּוֹתֵינוּ הִתִּירוּ שֶׁתֵּצֵא הַכַּלָּה בְּאַפִּרְיוֹן בְּתוֹךְ הָעִיר.
sentences.human_translation: In the last war, they decreed that a bride may not go out in a palanquin inside the city, but our Sages permitted a bride to go out in a palanquin inside the city,
sentences.llm_translation: In Pulumus the latter, they decreed that the bride should not go out in a palanquin within the city, and our Rabbis permitted the bride to go out in a palanquin within the city.

sentences.text: מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי מֵאִיר בָּטְלוּ מוֹשְׁלֵי מְשָׁלִים. מִשֶּׁמֵּת בֶּן עַזַּאי בָּטְלוּ הַשַּׁקְדָנִים. מִשֶּׁמֵּת בֶּן זוֹמָא בָּטְלוּ הַדַּרְשָׁנִים. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא בָּטַל כְּבוֹד הַתּוֹרָה. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי חֲנִינָא בֶּן דּוֹסָא בָּטְלוּ אַנְשֵׁי מַעֲשֶׂה. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי יוֹסֵי קְטֹנְתָּא פָּסְקוּ חֲסִידִים. וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמוֹ ״קְטֹנְתָּא״ — שֶׁהָיָה קְטֹנְתָּא שֶׁל חֲסִידִים.
sentences.human_translation: From when Rabbi Meir died, those who relate parables ceased; from when ben Azzai died, the diligent ceased; from when ben Zoma died, the exegetists ceased; from when Rabbi Akiva died, the honor of the Torah ceased; from when Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa died, the men of action ceased; from when Rabbi Yosei the Small died, the pious were no more. And why was he called the Small? Because he was the smallest of the pious,
sentences.llm_translation: From the death of Rabbi Meir, the interpreters of parables ceased. From the death of Ben Azzai, the almond trees ceased. From the death of Ben Zoma, the expounders ceased. From the death of Rabbi Akiva, the honor of the Torah ceased. From the death of Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa, the men of deeds ceased. From the death of Rabbi Yosei K'tanta, the pious ceased. And why was he called "K'tanta"? Because he was the smallest among the pious.

sentences.text: מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבָּן יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי בָּטַל זִיו הַחׇכְמָה. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל הַזָּקֵן בָּטַל כְּבוֹד הַתּוֹרָה, וּמֵתָה טׇהֳרָה וּפְרִישׁוּת. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בֶּן פִּאָבִי בָּטְלָה זִיו הַכְּהוּנָּה. מִשֶּׁמֵּת רַבִּי בָּטְלָ[ה] עֲנָוָה וְיִרְאַת חֵטְא.
sentences.human_translation: From when Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai died, the glory of wisdom ceased; from when Rabban Gamliel the Elder died, the honor of the Torah ceased, and purity and asceticism died. From when Rabbi Yishmael ben Pavi died, the glory of the priesthood ceased; from when Rabbi died, humility and fear of sin ceased.
sentences.llm_translation: From when Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai died, the splendor of wisdom ceased. From when Rabban Gamliel the Elder died, the honor of the Torah ceased, and purity and separation ceased. From when Rabbi Yishmael ben Piavi died, the radiance of the priesthood ceased. From when Rabbi died, humility and fear of sin ceased.

sentences.text: [ גְּמָ׳ ] תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: רַבִּי פִּנְחָס בֶּן יָאִיר אוֹמֵר: מִשֶּׁחָרַב בֵּית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ בּוֹשׁוּ חֲבֵרִים וּבְנֵי חוֹרִין, וְחָפוּ רֹאשָׁם, וְנִדַּלְדְּלוּ אַנְשֵׁי מַעֲשֶׂה, וְגָבְרוּ בַּעֲלֵי זְרוֹעַ וּבַעֲלֵי לָשׁוֹן, וְאֵין דּוֹרֵשׁ וְאֵין מְבַקֵּשׁ וְאֵין שׁוֹאֵל,
sentences.human_translation: The Sages taught: Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir says: From when the Temple was destroyed, the ḥaverim and free men were ashamed, and their heads were covered and men of action dwindled, and violent and smooth-talking men gained the upper hand, and none seek, and none ask, and none inquire
sentences.llm_translation: G'ma The Rabbis taught: Rabbi Pinchas ben Yair says: When the Temple was destroyed, the members of the community were ashamed, the free men were humiliated, the workers were shaken, the leaders of the arm and the leaders of the tongue prevailed, and no one inquired, and no one sought, and no one asked.

sentences.text: עַל מִי לָנוּ לְהִשָּׁעֵן עַל אָבִינוּ שֶׁבַּשָּׁמַיִם.
sentences.human_translation: Upon whom for us to rely? upon our Father in Heaven.
sentences.llm_translation: On whom shall we rely? On our Father in Heaven.

sentences.text: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הַגָּדוֹל אוֹמֵר: מִיּוֹם שֶׁחָרַב בֵּית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ שָׁרוֹ חַכִּימַיָּא לְמֶהֱוֵי כְּסָפְרַיָּא, וְסָפְרַיָּא כְּחַזָּנַיָּא, וְחַזָּנַיָּא כְּעַמָּא דְאַרְעָא, וְעַמָּא דְאַרְעָא
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer the Great says: From the day the Temple was destroyed, Scholars have begun to become like scribes and scribes have become like beadles, and beadles have become like ignoramuses, and ignoramuses
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer the Great says: Since the Temple was destroyed, wise men have become like scribes, scribes like synagogue attendants, synagogue attendants like common people, and common people
